headline: Technology Rout Pushes Nasdaq to Lowest Close Since 2014

text: The European Union's single market is "absolutely crucial" for embedding free trade in the 28-country bloc and should not be lost under EU reforms aimed at keeping Britain inside the EU, Bank of England Deputy Governor Andrew Bailey said on Friday.
headline: BoE's Bailey Says EU Single Market 'Absolutely Crucial'

text: Authorities say the death of a 5-year-old boy whose remains were found wrapped in a blanket and packed in a suitcase by the side of a Massachusetts highway has been ruled a homicide.
headline: Officials: Death of Boy Found Near Highway Ruled a Homicide

text: The free flow of data across the Atlantic, the lifeblood of modern business dealings, faces an uncertain future, despite a belated, high-level deal between European and U.S. officials this week.
headline: Showdown in Europe Over Privacy Has U.S. Firms Ducking for Cover

text: Swedish furniture giant IKEA has lost the right to use its own brand name in Indonesia after a legal battle with a local company that claimed the trademark, court documents released earlier this week showed.
headline: Sweden's IKEA Loses Right to Use Its Own Name in Indonesia

text: A senior Russian diplomat said on Friday Syrian opposition envoys who attended U.N.-mediated peace talks this week should have welcomed a government offensive because it targeted Islamist militants, rather than walk out of the parley.
headline: Syrian Opposition Should Welcome Aleppo Offensive as It Targets Militants-Russia

text: Saido Berahino's transfer wrangle has been keenly felt by West Bromwich Albion, according to manager Tony Pulis, who hopes the club will now benefit following an end to the "shenanigans" surrounding the striker's future.
headline: West Brom Manager Pulis Wants Berahino Boost

text: The Unha 3 rocket that launched the "Bright Star" satellite into space in 2012 is a symbol of North Korea's technological successes and a matter of great national pride. The country plans another launch to put Earth observation satellite into orbit this month. Although the equipment it will use is not yet known, the launch could also advance its military-use missile technology further.
headline: AP Photos: Rocket Models in North Korean Propaganda Displays

text: A researcher sits in a laboratory in Indonesia, his arms extended over clear plastic boxes buzzing with mosquitoes: over the next 20 minutes, tiny bumps develop on his skin as the insects bite dozens of times.
headline: In Indonesia, an Experiment With Bacteria to Tackle Zika

text: Slovakia's ruling leftists are slowly losing support a month before a parliamentary election and will likely not reach the  outright majority it currently enjoys, a second opinion poll in a row showed on Friday.
headline: New Slovakia Poll Shows Ruling Left's Lead Shrinks Before March Vote

text: Residents and traders in southern Nepal on Friday dismantled tents and roadblocks set up by protesters at a key border crossing, allowing trucks to cross freely from neighboring India for the first time in four months.
headline: Indian Trucks Cross Freely Into Nepal for First Time in Four Months

text: Nabil Shurafa's travel agency in Gaza was once packed with clients booking flights to London, Paris, New York or cities across the Arab world. These days, he's lucky if anyone comes in, as so few people can get out.
headline: Travel Agency in Isolated Gaza Recalls the 'Golden' 1950s

text: Audi's labor boss said he will "hold management responsible" for adopting a new leadership culture, raising pressure on the luxury carmaker to implement change as it grapples with its emissions scandal.
headline: Audi Labor Boss Presses Management for Culture Change

text: Bayern Munich coach Pep Guardiola has shrugged off suggestions of a potential conflict of interest after signing with Premier League's Manchester City for next season, saying he was quite capable of mult-tasking.
headline: Multi-Tasking No Problem for Man City-Bound Guardiola

text: A high-ranking member of Iran's elite Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC) and six Iranian Basij militia volunteers have been killed in fighting in Syria, semi-official Iranian media said on Friday.
headline: Iranian Revolutionary Guards General, 6 Basij Volunteers Killed in Syria-Media

text: A weeklong search for a Missouri couple wanted in a series of robberies and abductions across the South ended with one suspect dead and the other wounded Friday, after authorities say they chased the pair across the highway and through a rural neighborhood and exchanged gunfire with them in Florida's Panhandle.
headline: Couple Wanted in Crime Spree Led Police on Chase; 1 Killed

text: French police have rounded up hundreds of suspects and searched more than 3,000 homes under a state of emergency since the November extremist attacks on Paris — but much of the action involves drug cases or similar crime, not terrorism.
headline: French Activists Denounce Abuse of Authority After Attacks

text: Manchester City's top-of-the-table Premier League clash against Leicester City on Saturday and the game against third-placed Tottenham Hotspur the next weekend could be a "turning point", defender Bacary Sagna said in an interview published on Friday.
headline: Sagna Looks Ahead to 'Turning Point' in Man City's Season

text: The Czech defense minister says a military spy who was among five Czechs returned Thursday from Lebanon was seeking information about a fellow countryman kidnapped in Libya last year.
headline: Official: Spy Was in Lebanon to Help Kidnapped Czech

text: Residents in the southern Somali town of Marka say fighters from the Islamic extremist group al-Shabab have taken control there after the withdrawal of African Union forces.
headline: Islamic Extremists Take Control of Town in Southern Somalia

text: The patriarch of Russia's Orthodox Church will take part in an historic first meeting with the Roman Catholic pontiff on Feb. 12 because of the need for a joint response to the persecution of Christians in the Middle East, the Orthodox Church said.
headline: Pope, Russian Patriarch to Talk About Persecution of Christians

text: Swedish truck maker AB Volvo has posted a fourth quarter net profit of 2.59 billion kronor ($310 million), compared with a 2.98 billion kronor loss last year, on the back of cost cuts and brisk sales in Europe.
headline: Volvo Posts Higher 4th Quarter Profit on Brisk Europe Sales

text: A car bomb exploded Friday outside a U.N. mission police station in northern Mali, killing at least one Malian soldier and wounding several others, authorities said.
headline: Car Bomb Explodes at UN Base in Mali's Timbuktu

text: Vantage Goldfields said 87 workers trapped underground at a South African mine had been rescued, but emergency teams were searching for three missing workers after the company's Lily gold mine collapsed on Friday.
headline: Vantage Goldfields Says 87 Workers Rescued From Collapsed South African Mine, Three Workers Missing

text: Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos said on Friday that Republican members of the U.S. Congress had indicated their continuing support for Colombia's effort to achieve peace with leftist rebels and recover from years of civil war.
headline: Colombian Leader Says Received Assurances of Support From Republican U.S. Lawmakers

text: Republican presidential candidate Chris Christie has dismissed him as a puppet and former mentor Jeb Bush called him not fit to serve as up-and-coming Republican Marco Rubio becomes the man to beat in next week's New Hampshire primary.
headline: Rubio Under Attack as New Hampshire Primary Race Heats Up

text: Donors say Republican Jeb Bush's U.S. presidential campaign has not given them a green light to switch to rival establishment candidate Marco Rubio, whose strong third-place finish in this week's Iowa caucuses outshone the sixth-place Bush.
headline: Donors to White House Hopeful Jeb Bush Urged Not to Switch to Rubio

text: The top U.N. human rights official called on Friday for countries with the Zika virus to make available sexual and reproductive health counselling to women and uphold their right to terminate pregnancies.
headline: U.N. Rights Boss Urges Abortion Right Upheld in Zika Outbreak

text: Cattle, thin like their owners, wander in a parched riverbed. Desperate villagers barter a few fish for maize because there is no money for food. In this drought-stricken area of Zimbabwe, some people allege that who you know determines whether you'll get state food aid, with those out of favor with local officials going hungry.
headline: Drought-Stricken Zimbabwe Declares State of Disaster

text: Sheikh Salman's bid to succeed Sepp Blatter got a major boost Friday when the African soccer confederation announced it was backing the Bahraini royal for FIFA president.
headline: African Confederation Backs Sheikh Salman in FIFA Election

text: A total of 49 people have been detained in connection with chemical blasts in the Chinese port city of Tianjin last August that killed 165 people, the government said in a report on Friday while putting losses at more than $1 billion.
headline: China Says 49 Detained for Tianjin Blasts, Losses at $1 Billion

text: Pope Francis and the head of the Russian Orthodox Church will meet in Cuba next week in what could be a landmark step towards healing the 1,000-year-old rift between the Western and Eastern branches of Christianity.
headline: Pope, Russian Orthodox Patriarch to Hold Historic Meeting in Cuba

text: In an historic step to heal the 1,000-year schism that split Christianity, Pope Francis and the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church will meet in Cuba next week in an attempt to begin bridging the church's East-West divide.
headline: Historic Step: Pope, Russia Patriarch Meet in Cuba Feb. 12

text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel will travel to Ankara on Monday to meet with Turkey's prime minister as she tries to reduce the migrant influx to Europe, the German government said Friday.
headline: Germany's Merkel to Travel to Turkey Next Week Over Migrants

text: China's COSCO is expected to make an offer for Greece's rail network after becoming the sole bidder for the country's largest port, two people familiar with the matter said, as the state owned shipping giant forges ahead with a plan to build a European transhipment hub.
headline: After Piraeus Port, China's COSCO Eyes Greek Trains to Build Europe Hub-Sources

text: European clubs should be worried by Chinese football's display of economic might in the January transfer window, Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger said on Friday.
headline: China's Financial Might Worries Arsenal's Wenger

text: Poland is satisfied with the outcome of talks over a proposed EU-Britain deal with British Prime Minister David Cameron who is visiting Warsaw on Friday, head of the Polish ruling Law and Justice party Jaroslaw Kaczynski said.
headline: Poland's Kaczynski Says 'Satisfied' After Talks With Britain's Cameron

text: Deadly warehouse blasts that killed 165 people in a Chinese port city in August were triggered when a chemical stored in an unlicensed facility became too dry and caught fire, investigators announced Friday.
headline: China Probe Says Stored Chemical Caused Tianjin Blasts

text: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about today:
headline: 10 Things to Know for Today

text: The U.S. Air Force will deploy four Lockheed Martin Corp F-35 fighter jets to a different U.S. air base this month as it assesses whether the new warplane can be declared combat-ready by August as planned, a senior officer told Reuters on Thursday.
headline: U.S. Air Force Says Plans Test F-35 Deployment This Month

text: The recent pickup in euro zone economic growth will be maintained this year but the European Central Bank will have to ease policy again to boost weak inflation, according to the top forecaster for the currency bloc in Reuters polls last year.
headline: Top Euro Zone Economy Forecaster Optimistic on Growth

text: A Connecticut town is considering a program that trains teachers to use guns in the event of an active shooter, and Gov. Dannel P. Malloy has come down hard on the idea.
headline: Conn. Governor Critical of Town Considering Arming Teachers

text: Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu has vowed not to negotiate peace with Kurdish rebels until the group lays down its arms.
headline: Turkish PM: No Talks With PKK Before It Lays Down Arms

text: Iraq's top Shi'ite cleric said on Friday he would no longer deliver regular weekly sermons about political affairs, which for years have been a source of guidance for Iraqi politicians and his millions of followers.
headline: Iraq's Top Shi'ite Cleric Suspends Weekly Political Sermons

text: Vehicles passed through the main border point between Nepal and India on Friday after frustrated local residents forcefully removed barriers set up by ethnic protesters who blockaded the border to demand changes in the new constitution.
headline: Local Residents Open Main Blocked India-Nepal Border Point

text: Britain's top share index lost ground on Friday as investors digested a weaker than expected U.S. jobs reading, with miners pulled lower as copper dipped.
headline: FTSE Slips on Uncertainty After U.S. Jobs Data

text: European Union defense ministers huddled Friday with NATO's secretary general to discuss closer cooperation between the military alliance and the 28-nation bloc to tackle looming threats to the region.
headline: NATO Chief Meets EU Defense Ministers to Discuss Cooperation

text: South Africa's Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union said on Friday it wanted criminal charges to be brought against the owners and management of a collapsed mine operated by Vantage Goldfields should investigations reveal that negligence was involved.
headline: South Africa Union Wants Owners Charged if Mine Collapse Due to Negligence

text: Japan is on track to match its highest ever haul of gold medals at this year's Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, according to data and statistics company Infostrada Sports.
headline: Japan Set for Rich Medal Haul in Rio: Analysts

text: New Delhi's Feroz Shah Kotla ground has three more days to acquire the necessary paperwork to retain hosting rights for matches at the World Twenty20 tournament starting next month, the Indian cricket board (BCCI) said on Friday.
headline: Indian Board to Make Delhi T20 Venue Decision on Monday

text: British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond poured scorn on a UN working group report on Julian Assange, calling it ridiculous, and said the Wikileaks founder was a fugitive from justice.
headline: UK Foreign Secretary Calls U.N. Assange Report 'Ridiculous'

text: Tottenham Hotspur are in a "tough period" due to their new stadium project, team manager Mauricio Pochettino said, citing the experience of rival team Arsenal, who also suffered after the switch to the Emirates Stadium.
headline: Spurs in a 'Tough Period', Says Pochettino Ahead of Stadium Move

text: A Japanese volcano about 50 km (30 miles) from a nuclear plant erupted on Friday, shooting ash nearly 2 km into the night sky along with fountains of lava, but there were no immediate report of damage and operations at the power station were not affected.
headline: Japanese Volcano Erupts, Nearby Nuclear Plant Unaffected

text: One of Japan's most active volcanos erupted spectacularly Friday evening with a fiery blast that sent lava rolling down its slope.
headline: Sakurajima Volcano Erupts Spectacularly in Southern Japan

text: Olympic and world heptathlon champion Jessica Ennis-Hill is set to miss the indoor athletics season with an Achilles injury, disrupting her preparations for the defence of her title at the Rio Games in August.
headline: Olympic Champion Ennis-Hill to Miss Indoor Season

text: Paris St Germain have what it takes to reach rhe Champions League final this season after three consecutive quarter-final exits, Argentine winner Angel Di Maria said on Friday.
headline: PSG Equipped to Reach Champions League Final, Says Di Maria

text: Turkey is not planning a military incursion into Syria and Russian talk of such action is propaganda, a senior Turkish government official said on Friday.
headline: Russian Talk of Turkish Incursion in Syria Is Propaganda: Senior Turkish Official

text: Tens of thousands of Syrians fled an intensifying Russian assault around Aleppo on Friday, and aid workers said they feared the major city could soon fall under a full government siege.
headline: Thousands Flee as Russian-Backed Offensive Threatens to Besiege Aleppo

text: A building collapsed above a gold mine in South Africa on Friday, trapping dozens of people before they were rescued. After several hours, three people remained missing, a union spokesman said.
headline: South Africa: All but 3 Rescued After Collapse at Gold Mine

text: The Albanian Environment Ministry says Parliament has passed a 10-year moratorium on chopping down trees for industry or export purposes.
headline: Albania Passes 10-Year Moratorium to Stop Cutting Wood

text: Donor nations have pledged to give more than $10 billion by 2020 to meet Syrian needs. The pledges came during a conference in London on Thursday, described by U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon as the single biggest humanitarian fundraising event ever.
headline: Factbox-Top Donor Pledges for Syrian Humanitarian Needs

text: Some San Francisco Bay Area residents hoping to rent their homes for thousands of dollars a night to deep-pocketed Super Bowl attendees are finding themselves short of the goal line.
headline: Super Bowl Home Rental Prices Not Meeting Stratospheric Hopes

text: United Nations Syria envoy Staffan de Mistura will brief the U.N. Security Council via videolink on Friday, two days after he suspended peace talks and said the big powers needed to do more to support him, U.N. spokesman Ahmad Fawzi said.
headline: U.N. Syria Envoy to Brief Security Council on Friday: Spokesman

text: The European transfer window is not so European any more, with Chinese clubs outspending the continent's richest clubs in January to prove that the country is now a genuine power in attracting the world's best players.
headline: Big Spending Chinese Clubs Show Global Ambitions

text: More people are visiting the national forest surrounding Sedona.
headline: Visitation Up in National Forest Surrounding Sedona

text: British Prime Minister David Cameron found support Friday for a renegotiated deal with the European Union from Poland and Denmark, marking a positive start to a two-week tour of European capitals aimed at winning over European partners to his plans for a looser union with the bloc.
headline: Poland Says It Wins Protection for Poles in British EU Deal

text: The chief executive of Vantage Goldfields mine in South Africa's northeastern Mpumalanga province said on Friday that about 115 workers had been trapped after one its mines collapsed, but most had been rescued.
headline: Most of 115 Miners in South African Vantage Goldfields Mine Collapse Rescued-CEO

text: The Latest on Syria (all times Syria local):
headline: The Latest: Kerry Says Russia, Assad Not Complying With UN

text: India have gambled on the fitness of Mohammed Shami by including the injury-prone paceman in the 15-man squad named on Friday for next month's World Twenty20 tournament on home soil.
headline: India Gamble on Paceman Shami for World T20

text: Some 76 mine workers have been brought to the surface after a mine owned by Vantage Goldfields collapsed in South Africa on Friday, a police spokesman said.
headline: Nearly 80 People Rescued in Collapsed South African Mine-Police

text: Florida's history of fighting off mosquito-borne outbreaks puts the state in perhaps better position than most when it comes to the Zika virus.
headline: Florida Readies for a Fight With Zika Virus

text: London Underground maintenance workers are planning a series of strikes in a dispute over safety.
headline: Union Calls Series of Strikes on London Underground

text: BNP Paribas pledged a higher dividend payout and said its priority was to keep its return on equity at 10 percent beyond 2016 after it announced further cost cutting measures for its investment bank.
headline: BNP Paribas Sets Out Cost Cuts, Reassures on Capital

text: Islamic State militants have slipped into Europe disguised as refugees, the head of Germany's domestic intelligence agency (BfV) said on Friday, a day after security forces thwarted a potential IS attack in Berlin.
headline: German Spy Agency Says ISIS Sending Fighters Disguised as Refugees

text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls is appealing to legislators to approve a divisive bill, prompted by last year's attacks on Paris, that would revoke the French citizenship of convicted terrorists with dual nationality.
headline: French Premier Pushes Law to Revoke Terrorists' Citizenship

text: Design houses Burberry and Tom Ford on Friday announced new strategies that will allow them to close the gap between the runway and retail in order to get clothing and accessories more quickly to customers in different climates around the world.
headline: Burberry, Tom Ford Align Runway Shows With Retail Availability

text: "Dammit, Janet," there's another musical coming to television, and Victoria Justice could not be happier to hear those words.
headline: Victoria Justice Talks 'Rocky Horror' at Super Bowl

text: The IAAF is investigating the authenticity of a two-decade-old letter published in Chinese media that suggests state-sanctioned doping in the 1990s, and casts doubt on the longstanding world records set by Wang Junxia in the women's 3,000 and 10,000 meters.
headline: IAAF Looking Into Claims of State-Sanctioned Doping in China

text: An attorney told a Baltimore judge Friday that a witness who could have provided an alibi for the convicted killer at the center of the popular "Serial" podcast would have been "critical" in the man's first trial, had she been contacted by his original defense team.
headline: Lawyer: Omission of Witness Crippled 'Serial' Case's Defense

text: The European Union will adapt global bank capital rules to ease the burden on smaller lenders and encourage more investment in companies and infrastructure, the bloc's financial services chief said on Friday.
headline: EU's Hill Says Will Alter Global Bank Capital Rules to Suit Europe

text: European Union proposals for keeping Britain in the EU risk distorting competition in banking unless they are applied carefully, the bloc's banking watchdog said on Friday.
headline: Proposals to Keep Britain in EU Must Not Distort Banking Rules-Watchdog

text: Formula One has lost another of its principals.
headline: F1 Team Principals Are a Disappearing Breed

text: Taiwan's Foxconn is aiming to finalize a deal to acquire Japan's Sharp Corp by the end of the month, after the two firms reached a consensus on most points, Foxconn Chief Executive Officer Terry Gou said.
headline: Foxconn Says Agreed With Sharp on Most Points of a Takeover Deal

text: Russia is not eschewing political or diplomatic ways to settle the conflict in Syria, the Kremlin said on Friday, while making clear it would continue providing military assistance to the Syrian government.
headline: Kremlin Says Backs Syria Peace, but Will Continue to Support Assad

text: Romanian police have classified the death of a British travel writer as suspicious, almost a month after his decomposing body was found in his Bucharest apartment.
headline: Romania: British Travel Writer's Death Treated as Suspicious

text: Chinese officials have issued warnings to seed dealers and farmers not to use unapproved genetically modified seeds in the country's main crop belt, shortly after Greenpeace said it had found widespread GM contamination in corn.
headline: China Cracks Down on Illegal GM Crops Ahead of Syngenta Deal

text: Natalie Keepers told a judge that she was bullied — just like the 13-year-old girl she is accused of plotting to kill.
headline: Woman Charged in Teen's Death Says She, Too, Was Bullied

text: Combine a rapidly aging population, a depleted work force and leaky finances and any country's pension system would be in trouble. For debt-hobbled, unemployment-plagued Greece, it's a nightmare.
headline: Why Pensions Are the New Flashpoint in Greece's Crisis

text: Thousands of Syrians rushed toward the Turkish border Friday, fleeing a fierce government offensive and intense Russian airstrikes near Syria's largest city of Aleppo.
headline: Thousands More Syrians Rush Toward Turkey to Flee Fighting

text: Britain on Friday said it would contest a United Nations panel opinion that Wikileaks founder Julian Assange was a victim of arbitrary detention and said the computer hacker would be arrested if he left the embassy.
headline: Britain Says to Challenge U.N. Panel Opinion on Assange, Plans to Arrest Him

text: Some 49 miners have so far been rescued after a mine shaft collapsed in eastern South Africa, trapping about 100 workers, emergency services group ER24 said on Friday.
headline: Nearly 50 Miners Rescued After South Africa Shaft Collapses: Emergency Services

text: The tiny South Pacific kingdom of Tonga said Friday it has a Zika epidemic after five people tested positive for the virus and another 265 are suspected of having it.
headline: Tonga Declares Zika Epidemic After 5 Confirmed Cases

text: Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere has admitted that he often finds it difficult to remain positive in his constant battle against the injury problems that have hampered his club and international career.
headline: Wilshere Jaded by Constant Battle Against Injuries

text: The U.S. dollar rebounded against a basket of major currencies on Friday after data showed a pickup in U.S. wages in January, suggesting greater inflation and denting the view that the Federal Reserve would not hike rates at all this year.
headline: Dollar Gains After U.S. Data Suggests Possible 2016 Fed Rate Hikes

text: The Ukrainian government has accused Russia-backed rebels in eastern Ukraine of violating the shaky truce with large-caliber weapons.
headline: Fighting Flares Up in Eastern Ukraine

text: Malian troops backed by U.N. helicopters stormed a U.N. police base in the city of Timbuktu and recaptured it from suspected Islamist militants who had seized it hours before on Friday, the United Nations said.
headline: U.N. Police Base in Mali's Timbuktu Retaken From Islamist Militants

text: The Swedish government on Friday rejected the conclusions of a United Nations panel report saying Wikileaks founder Julian Assange's stay in Ecuador's London embassy amounts to "unlawful detention".
headline: Swedish Government Rejects U.N. Criticism Over Assange

text: Almost 90 miners were rescued and three other workers were missing after a cave-in at a gold mine in the northeast of South Africa on Friday, mine owner Vantage Goldfields said.
headline: Three Missing, 87 Rescued After South Africa Mine Collapse

text: Pakistan's Prime Minister on Friday called for resolving the lingering issue of Kashmir in accordance with U.N. Security Council resolutions, saying the credibility of the global organization will be at stake if it fails to implement its own decisions.
headline: Pakistan Commemorates 'Kashmir Day'

text: Polish Prime Minister Beata Szydlo reiterated on Friday that Poland wanted Britain to stay in the European Union and said her cabinet supported some of its demands on reforming the block.
headline: Poland Wants Britain in EU, Backs Some of Cameron's Proposals

text: The Latest on the U.N. panel's determination that Julian Assange has been arbitrarily detained (all times local):
headline: The Latest: Ecuadorean Minister Calls for Assange to Go Free

text: HONG KONG - The European Parliament has called for the immediate release of five Hong Kong booksellers detained in China, a case that has grabbed global headlines and rattled the diplomatic and business community in the Asia financial centre.
headline: European Parliament Calls for Release of HK Booksellers Detained in China

text: Japan has deployed PAC-3 missile batteries in the heart of Tokyo to shoot down any incoming rocket debris. South Korea is reportedly mobilizing two Aegis-equipped destroyers. The U.S. is already gunning to punish Pyongyang for what it says will be a ballistic missile test in the guise of a space launch.
headline: Experts Say Launch Won't Bring N. Korea Much Closer to ICBM

text: Russia's ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, Alexei Borodavkin, said on Thursday Russia expected talks aimed at resolving the Syria crisis to resume no later than Feb. 25, Russian news agencies reported.
headline: Russia Expects Syria Talks to Resume by Feb. 25-Ambassador to UN

text: The European Union will do whatever it can to improve export conditions for the countries bearing the brunt of Syria's refugee crisis, including possible trade preferences, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Thursday.
headline: EU May Give Syrian Refugee Host Countries Trade Preferences-Merkel

text: The White House said on Thursday it was hopeful that Syria peace talks suspended by the United Nations in Geneva would be back on track by the end of the month.
headline: White House Hopeful Syria Peace Talks Will Resume by the End of February

text: Those helping support the regime of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad are committing war crimes, Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said on Thursday.
headline: Turkish PM Says Those Helping Assad Are Committing War Crimes

text: Saudi Arabia said on Thursday it was ready to participate in any ground operations in Syria if the U.S.-led alliance decides to start such operations, an adviser to the Saudi defence minister said.
headline: Saudi Says Ready to Take Part in Any U.S.-Led Ground Operations in Syria

text: A conference of donor nations raised $11 billion for Syrian humanitarian needs over the next four years, British Prime Minister David Cameron said on Thursday as the event in London drew to a close.
headline: Syria Donor Conference Raises $11 Billion for 2016-2020-PM Cameron

text: Russia said on Thursday it suspected Turkey was preparing a military incursion into Syria, as a Syrian army source said Aleppo would soon be encircled by government forces with Russian air support.
headline: Russia and Turkey Trade Accusations Over Syria

text: Russia's intensification of air strikes in Syria is damaging to  peace talks in Geneva that the U.S.-alliance strongly supports, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said on Friday.
headline: Russian Strikes Undermining Syrian Peace Talks-NATO Chief

text: A U.N. panel of independent experts said on Friday that Wikileaks founder Julian Assange was being detained arbitrarily in the Ecuadorian embassy in London and should be released and compensated.
headline: Assange Should Be Released and Compensated, U.N. Panel Says

text: A Russian proposal to set up an advisory body in Amman to coordinate actions in Syria was rejected by the United States and its Western allies, Interfax news agency quoted Russian Deputy Defense Minister Anatoly Antonov as saying on Friday.
headline: Russia Says West Rejected Proposal for Syria Coordination Center: Interfax

text: It started more than five years ago as what appeared to be a fairly simple sex crime case: two women in Sweden came forward to accuse Julian Assange of sexual misconduct.
headline: Assange Sex Case Sinks in International Quagmire

text: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange called on Britain and Sweden on Friday to let him freely leave the Ecuadorian embassy in London after a U.N. panel ruled he had been arbitrarily detained and should be awarded compensation.
headline: WikiLeaks' Assange Calls on Sweden, Britain to Allow Him Freedom After U.N. Panel Report

text: Healthcare devices maker Halma Plc said it had bought CenTrak Inc, a privately owned maker of sensors, for about $140 million (95.9 million pounds), expanding its footprint in the U.S. healthcare market.
headline: Halma Buys Healthcare Sensors Maker CenTrak for About $140 Million

text: A police group's proposal that law enforcement officers be required to do more than what's minimally required by law in violent encounters has spurred anger and pushback from leading national groups representing chiefs and rank-and-file sworn officers.
headline: Police Officials Quarrel Over Effort to Raise Bar on Force

text: The Obama administration is struggling to find the right mix of military and diplomatic moves to stop the Islamic State in Libya, where the extremist group has taken advantage of the political chaos in the country to gain a foothold with worrying implications for the U.S. and Europe — particularly Italy, just 300 miles away.
headline: US Struggling to Build Anti-Islamic State Strategy in Libya

text: The United States has deployed missile defense systems that will work with the Japanese and South Korean militaries to track a rocket North Korea says it will launch some time over an 18-day period beginning Monday.
headline: U.S. and Allies Aim to Track North Korean Rocket; Launch Window From Monday

text: Stung by his second-place finish in Iowa, Donald Trump is facing new pressure to prove he can translate his massive crowds and poll leads into election wins. And his team appeared intent to demonstrate on Thursday that they'd learned from any past mistakes.
headline: Trump Campaign Shows a Different Side After Iowa Loss

text: For months, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have campaigned against each other with a velvet touch, eager to distinguish their race for the Democratic presidential nomination from the combative contest taking place in the Republican primary.
headline: Debate Takeaways: Clinton, Sanders Mix It Up Over Wall St.

text: Luxembourg Foreign Minister Jean Asselborn appealed to Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday to help bring about a ceasefire in Syria as tens of thousands Syrians flee aerial bombardments on the city of Aleppo.
headline: Luxembourg's Asselborn Urges Putin to Help With Cease Fire in Syria

text: Myanmar democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi's party on Friday nominated Shwe Mann, one of the country's most powerful politicians, to head a prominent legal advisory panel, as the freshly-elected parliament prepares to choose a new president.
headline: Myanmar's Suu Kyi Names Former General to Head Key Advisory Panel

text: Protesting chauffeurs have moved to Paris' city center after having disrupted access to the Charles de Gaulle airport for a few hours, amid tensions between traditional taxis and app-based car services as the government loosens regulations in the evolving sector.
headline: Protesting Chauffeurs Disrupt Access to Paris Airport

text: The latest Democratic debate found Hillary Clinton in a defensive crouch about her Wall Street ties and making iffy claims about that longtime relationship. Rival Bernie Sanders offered a fumbling account of a campaign ad that boasted of endorsements that were bogus.
headline: AP FACT CHECK: Clinton, Sanders Missteps

text: Urban Meyer has the cache and the national championship rings. Jim Harbaugh mixes a khakis-wearing sensibility with a sense of panache.
headline: 'Right Fit' Is the Sell in B10 Recruiting, Sideshow or Not

text: Back up a moment from the brawl between Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders over who is the real progressive and whether one can be that and be pragmatic at the same time.

text: On the rise in a tightening race, Marco Rubio shouldered intensifying attacks Friday from moderate-leaning Republicans who fear a strong Rubio showing in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary could spell the end for their frazzled presidential campaigns.

text: Austria will extend its border controls if Turkey does not take back refugees picked up at sea on their way to Greece, Chancellor Werner Faymann said in an interview with the daily Oesterreich, being published on Sunday.

text: Three members of Britain's special forces were injured in fighting with Islamic State gunmen in Iraq, the Mirror newspaper reported on Saturday without giving any details about its sources.

text: For a mere $3,000, you can attend the Super Bowl.

text: One person was killed and seven were injured when a gunman opened fire inside a crowded Florida strip club early on Saturday, police said.

text: Satellite images taken this week of North Korea's Sohae rocket launch site show apparent fueling activity seen in the past shortly before a rocket launch, a U.S. think-tank said, as U.S government officials signaled that a launch could occur as early as Monday.

text: The premier of an Australian state offered on Saturday to look after a group of asylum seekers facing repatriation to a camp on a remote Pacific island, adding to opposition to the federal government's policy of offshore detention.

text: North Korea launched a long-range rocket on Sunday carrying what it has called a satellite, but its neighbors and Washington denounced the launch as a missile test, conducted in defiance of U.N. sanctions and just weeks after a nuclear bomb test.

text: While Metallica has steadily attracted more of a mainstream audience throughout its 35-year career, frontman James Hetfield feels they will never play the Super Bowl, and he doesn't seem to mind.

text: European Union nations anxious to stem the flow of asylum-seekers coming through the Balkans are increasingly considering sending more help to non-member Macedonia as a better way to protect European borders instead of relying on EU member Greece.

text: Iran's constitutional watchdog, the hard-line Guardian Council, reversed a ban on 1,500 candidates who had registered to run in Feb. 26 parliamentary elections, state media reported on Saturday.

text: Hillary Clinton told voters in the latest Democratic debate there's "hardly anything you don't know about me."

text: An Iowa couple whose son is heading to Iraq made such an impression on Republican presidential hopeful Chris Christie that he's made them a staple of his New Hampshire campaign speech this week. But while the couple came away from the encounter just as impressed, they supported rival Marco Rubio in the state's caucuses.

text: With a possible end in sight to a massive 15-week gas leak, anxious residents displaced from a Los Angeles neighborhood are skeptical a fix is near and worry they may be forced to return too soon to unhealthy homes.

text: Authorities have arrested the ex-roommate of a woman whose body was found walled up inside a Southern California apartment six years after she disappeared.

text: Four-nation talks aimed at ending Afghanistan's 15-year war concluded Saturday with a call for direct negotiations between the government and the Taliban by the end of February, but recent battlefield advances by the insurgents could make it hard to coax them to the table.

text: Cleveland Browns quarterback Johnny Manziel is the subject of a criminal investigation regarding a domestic violence complaint, Dallas police announced late on Friday.

text: The Latest on the collapse of a construction crane, which killed a pedestrian (all times local):

text: A mine manager says rescue teams have removed 3,500 tons of debris in their search for three people still trapped underground after a collapse at a South African mine.

text: A New York City police officer charged with fatally shooting an unarmed black man in an unlit Brooklyn stairwell is expected to take the stand in his own defense on Monday at his trial for manslaughter.

text: California voters embraced the idea of building the nation's first real high-speed rail system, which promised to whisk travelers from San Francisco to Los Angeles in under three hours, a trip that can take six hours or more by car. Eight years after they approved funding for it, construction is years behind schedule and legal, financial and logistical delays plague the $68 billion project.

text: The inhabitants of a northern Spanish mountain village have taken part in an age-old Carnival festival that re-enacts a legendary confrontation between good and evil.

text: Wales drew 16-16 with defending champions Ireland in an absorbing Six Nations opener on Sunday, clawing back a 13-point first half deficit to take the lead before Johnny Sexton levelled with a late penalty.

text: The Japanese government fund may reduce its stake in Tokyo Electric Power Co to below 50 percent in 2017 if the company achieves its goals including its first bond issuance in six years, the company's president said.
headline: Japan's Tepco Works Hard to Pull Out From Government Control

text: Authorities say a Massachusetts man who was struck by a falling tree limb after a snowstorm has died from his injuries.

text: U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said he does not have to win the New Hampshire primary vote on Tuesday to secure the nomination, apparently tamping down expectations despite holding a double-digit lead in that state's polls.

text: The Coen brothers' "Hail, Caesar!" and the Jane Austen-monster mashup "Pride and Prejudice and Zombies" followed distantly behind "Kung Fu Panda 3," which remained on top of the box office over Super Bowl weekend.

text: Hamburg SV drew 1-1 at home to Cologne in the Bundesliga on Sunday, stretching their winless streak to six league matches and dropping closer to the relegation zone.

text: Richard Gasquet won a 13th career singles title by beating  fellow Frenchman Paul-Henri Mathieu 7-5 6-4 in the Open Sud de France final in Montpellier on Sunday.

text: Jordan's planning minister says his country has been promised easier trade terms by the international community, potentially generating large-scale investment and "hundreds of thousands of job opportunities."

text: The Denver Broncos and their top defense haven't seen anything quite like Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers, the No. 1 scoring offense in the league.

text: Cam Newton didn't just stumble into becoming the NFL's best player.

text: Caroline Garcia followed Kristina Mladenovic's earlier win by beating Camila Giorgi 6-3, 6-4 as France clinched a spot in the Fed Cup semifinals on Sunday with a comprehensive 4-1 win against Italy in their first-round tie.

text: A delegation including American rights activist Angela Davis has been turned away from a Spanish prison where it tried to visit imprisoned Basque separatist politician Arnaldo Otegi.

text: A federal judge is being asked to revoke the bond for one of four men accused of raising money for a former al-Qaida leader.

text: A shooting erupted inside a nightclub packed with hundreds of people in the city's tourist district early Sunday, killing two people and injuring 10 others, authorities said.

text: A broad legal challenge has led more than 20 towns in Texas to ease restrictions over the last few months on where sex offenders can live instead of fight a costly battle in court.

text: A Libyan parliamentarian says an airstrike hit a medical technology college in a populated area of the eastern city of Darna, killing four people, including a woman and her son.

text: Jessica Ries settles in behind the counter of Tip Top Tux and phones a couple to remind them of an upcoming fitting before their wedding. In the back room, beyond the dapper mannequins and vest swatches of pink, yellow and blue, a tote filled with review packets for 24 of her Hayward Elementary School students awaits her attention if she gets any down time.
headline: Low Pay Forces South Dakota Teachers to Hold 2nd, 3rd Jobs

text: When this Long Island village switched on its "ring of steel" last fall, it knew it was getting a potent policing tool. The system of 27 cameras would scan the license plate of every single vehicle that rolled into town. If a wanted criminal drove through, the system would sound an alert. If someone burglarized a house, the data could be mined to see who was on the road at the time.
headline: License Plate Readers a Double-Edged Sword for NY Village

text: British Prime Minister David Cameron is calling for an urgent review of how pregnant women are handled by prisons in light of figures showing 100 babies spent time in prison last year.
headline: UK's Cameron: Review How Prisons Treat Pregnant Women

text: Bournemouth 0 Arsenal 2
headline: Arsenal Back in Title Race With Win at Bournemouth

text: South Carolina coach Dawn Staley thinks Connecticut's Breanna Stewart is a sublime player and competitor who has transcended the game. Staley would know, having redefined point guard play as the game's best player a quarter-century ago.

text: An upstate New York town that repeatedly found itself without power for days during a string of storms is planning a dramatic step by pulling its municipal buildings entirely off the electric grid.

text: Saudi Arabia's King Salman on Sunday called on other countries not to interfere in the kingdom's internal affairs in what appeared to be a rebuke to Riyadh's main foe Iran, which it accuses of attempting to stir unrest.

text: James Wanda, a senior at Pennsylvania's Lafayette College and one of two black computer science majors in his class, says at times he has felt pressure to succeed not just for himself, but for his entire race.

text: Ireland's senior coalition party will ensure high earners do not make "extravagant gains" from planned income tax cuts and also raise the minimum wage by 15 percent by 2021 if re-elected, Finance Minister Michael Noonan said on Sunday.

text: A pedestrian killed by a collapsing crane was eulogized Sunday as a man of kindness and generosity as the final remnants of the crumpled steel were removed from the Manhattan street where they fell.

text: Somewhere in the Dallas area, a retired man sitting in a home office is making social media videos backing Japanese right-wing views that have made him a celebrity among hawks in the Asian country.

text: The International Committee of the Red Cross said Sunday it is temporarily closing its Gaza office after protesters repeatedly tried to storm it.

text: Honda Motor Co's order that its U.S. dealers stop selling some 2.2 million of the automakers' most popular models is compounding financial and regulatory headaches for car dealers stuck with millions of vehicles that have potentially hazardous air bags or other safety defects.

text: Experts on microcephaly, the birth defect that has sparked alarm in the current Zika virus outbreak, say they are struck by the severity of a small number of cases they have reviewed from Brazil.

text: British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond said on Sunday he had spoken with his Japanese counterpart Fumio Kishida and both had agreed the U.N. Security Council should take strong action against North Korea for launching a long-range rocket.

text: Security video footage taken at Mogadishu airport shows two men handing what looks like a laptop computer to the suspected suicide bomber after he passed through the security checkpoint, Somalia's government spokesman said Sunday.

text: Giant earthmoving machines beep and grind as they drop 17-ton scoops of coal ash and dirt into dozens of railroad cars lined up for two-thirds of a mile at a site along the Virginia-North Carolina border, where the country's largest electricity company was responsible for one of the worst spills of the toxic, liquefied waste in U.S. history.

text: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on Sunday discussed a rocket launch by North Korea in violation of U.N. Security Council resolutions with Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida, Russia's foreign ministry said.

text: A Purple Heart awarded to a soldier from New Hampshire killed in World War II's Battle of the Bulge that turned up recently after a woman's death has brought together two branches of a family that never knew of the other's existence.

text: Defending champion Czech Republic beat host Romania 3-2 Sunday to advance to the semifinals of the Fed Cup.

text: Police say a dispute in a Rochester, New York, bar spilled outside and erupted into gunfire that left one man dead and seven other people injured.

text: The Latest on the race for president in the window between the Republican and Democratic debates and the 2016 New Hampshire presidential primary on Tuesday: (all times local):

text: A professor at an evangelical university near Chicago who got in trouble after saying Muslims and Christians worship the same God will leave the school, according to a joint statement released by Wheaton College on Saturday night.

text: Napoli beat 10-man visitors Carpi 1-0 and Juventus won 2-0 at second-bottom Frosinone on Sunday as the leading pair extended their Serie A winning streaks to move further ahead at the top of the table.

text: German authorities have ordered the closure of Maple Bank after the Canadian-owned company was investigated for alleged tax evasion and money laundering.

text: Tapping into Canadian hydropower is hardly a new concept in energy-starved New England. But Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker's proposal to authorize long-term contracts between utilities and hydropower producers is being viewed in some quarters as a potential game-changer for the region.

text: Four people were killed in Burundi on Saturday night, including a child selling boiled eggs at a bar, when three grenades hit  the capital Bujumbura, residents said.

text: The Netherlands' dream Fed Cup run continued as Kiki Bertens crushed Russia's Svetlana Kuznetsova 6-1 6-4 in Moscow on Sunday to send them into the semi-finals of the team competition for the first time since 1997.

text: Belinda Bencic and Australian Open doubles champion Martina Hingis sent Switzerland to the Fed Cup semifinals with a 3-2 win over Germany on Sunday.

text: Spanish police arrested seven people with suspected links to Islamist militant groups on Sunday in a dawn raid in the Mediterranean regions of Alicante and Valencia and in Spain's north African enclave Ceuta, the Interior Ministry said.

text: Saudi Arabia's oil minister Ali al-Naimi discussed cooperation between OPEC members and other oil producers to stabilize the global oil market with his Venezuelan counterpart on Sunday, state news agency SPA reported.

text: A bus has exploded in central London — but this time it's only for a movie.

text: Bootleg liquor has killed at least two dozen people in a  village in Indonesia's Central Java province over the last few days, MetroTV said on Sunday quoting police.

text: Volkswagen will offer generous compensation packages to the roughly 600,000 U.S. owners of diesel vehicles whose emissions are over the legal limit, the head of its claims fund told a German paper.

text: A former top adviser says the late Margaret Thatcher would have supported the proposed deal outlined this week to keep Britain inside the 28-nation European Union.

text: The rapidly spreading Zika virus is discouraging many Americans from traveling to Latin America and the Caribbean, with 41 percent of those aware of the disease saying they are less likely to take such a trip, a Reuters/Ipsos poll shows.

text: Former Leicester City manager Martin O'Neill believes Saturday's stunning victory over Manchester City could spur the Foxes to become the most unexpected English champions since his Nottingham Forest side of 38 years ago.

text: A second autopsy on the body of an Italian found slain in Egypt reveals that the doctoral student suffered "inhuman, animal-like" violence, Italy's interior minister said Sunday as he pressed Egypt's president to fully cooperate with the criminal investigation.

text: Aid trucks and ambulances entered Syria from Turkey on Sunday to help tens of thousands of people who have fled an escalating government assault on Aleppo, as air strikes targeted villages on the road linking the city to the Turkish border.

text: Algerian lawmakers passed constitutional reforms on Sunday proposed by President Abdelaziz Bouteflika after the 2011 "Arab Spring" uprisings, including reinstating a two-term limit for the presidency and boosting parliamentary powers.

text: There are several detained dual citizens in Iran, most of whom  face espionage charges, the judiciary spokesman was quoted as saying on Sunday, although he did not give details of any individual cases.

text: The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) condemned North Korea's rocket launch on Sunday, saying it was in direct violation of United Nations Security Council resolutions.

text: (Withdrawing old story accidentally published)

text: At the unofficial schools run by Syrian activist group Kesh Malek in opposition-held districts of Aleppo, the children don't go outside to play during breaks in case a barrel bomb should drop from the sky.

text: A top official in the United Arab Emirates said Sunday that his country is prepared to send ground troops to Syria to fight Islamic State militants as part of an international coalition.

text: Lindsey Vonn is getting some competition for the overall World Cup title although she is still comfortably ahead.

text: With less than two days until New Hampshire voters go to the polls, Hillary Clinton took a trip to Michigan. text: When Hungary's prime minister had a secret five-hour meeting in a secluded mountain resort with the most powerful person in Poland, he didn't convene with his counterpart or the Polish president.

text: New data-sharing rules could be introduced in Britain from the end of this year to encourage innovation and competition in banking, an industry working group said on Tuesday.

text: So you thought the Panthers and Broncos would put up a lot more points in Super Bowl 50, that Carolina quarterback Cam Newton would score at least once and probably be named the game's most valuable player?

text: Police in Memphis, Tennessee, say one of their off-duty officers has shot a person at a home in the nearby Mississippi city of Southaven.

text: Gouging by oil companies could be one reason California drivers pay about 76 cents more for a gallon of regular gas than motorists elsewhere in the nation, a state government panel was told Monday.

text: Watching a lone browser in his Sydney Chinatown shop, Bing Chen is worried business is being squeezed this Lunar New Year by what's ailing the world economy at large - the weakest Chinese economy in 25 years.

text: The U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Monday it is expanding a defect investigation of 856,000 Fiat Chrysler SUVs and cars because the vehicles may roll away after drivers exit, thinking they have put the transmission in Park. The government's investigation covers the 2014-15 Jeep Grand Cherokee SUV, 2012-14 Dodge Charger and Chrysler 300. The vehicles under investigation have "E-shift" gear-shifts that operate electronically.

text: U.S. stocks closed sharply lower on Monday following a steep sell-off in materials, financials and technology stocks. The market pared its losses by the end of the day but still ended down for the second day in a row. The Nasdaq composite index closed almost 20 percent below its record high last year.
