text: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's campaign chair denied a Monday report that she is considering staff changes after the New Hampshire nominating contest on Tuesday.
headline: Clinton Campaign Denies Staffing Changes in Works

text: Two brothers from Cuba's preeminent baseball family have abandoned a Cuban team traveling in the Dominican Republic, presumably to defect and later seek professional careers in the United States, official Cuban media reported on Monday.
headline: Cuban Baseball Stars, the Gurriel Brothers, Abandon Team

text: Verizon Communications Inc has given Tim Armstrong, chief executive officer of its AOL unit, a leading role in exploring a possible bid for Yahoo Inc's assets, Bloomberg reported, citing a person with knowledge of the situation.
headline: Verizon Enlists AOL CEO to Explore Yahoo Deal: Bloomberg

text: Academy Award winner Sofia Coppola will make her operatic debut in May, directing a new production of Giuseppe Verdi's romantic tragedy "La Traviata", Rome's opera house said on Monday.
headline: Academy Award Winner Sofia Coppola to Direct First Opera in Rome

text: White House hopefuls Donald Trump and Jeb Bush opened political hostilities on Monday as Republican and Democratic candidates stormed across New Hampshire in a final flurry of events before the state's crucial first-in-the-nation primary.
headline: Trump Versus Jeb in New Hampshire on Day Before Crucial Primary

text: Iraq will send additional troops to a base outside the northern Islamic State-held city of Mosul.
headline: Iraq Will Send More Troops to Base Outside Mosul

text: To doubters of its strategy for defeating the Islamic State, the Obama administration likes to tout its coalition of 66 nations and claim strength in numbers. But a year and a half into the war, some administration officials are acknowledging that this supposed source of strength has its own weaknesses.
headline: US Faces Shortcomings in Coalition-Building for Anti-IS War

text: From the Philippines to North Korea and Indonesia people ushered in the Year of the Monkey with traditional dragon and lion dances, games and firecrackers to drive away evil spirits and bring good luck.
headline: Year of the Monkey Marked With Celebrations Throughout Asia

text: It's been 100 years since New Hampshire held its first presidential primary, and it seems like some of the current candidates have been hanging around for nearly that long. More than a few started popping up a full two years before Tuesday's state election, and nearly all have spent recent months hosting town hall meetings, holding rallies and meeting voters.
headline: Next Up: New Hampshire Set to Vote in Nation's First Primary

text: Libya's air force chief of staff says a fighter jet was shot down while carrying out airstrikes against Islamic militants.
headline: Militants Shoot Down Libyan Fighter Jet

text: When Marshawn Lynch was brought to Seattle early in the 2010 season, he was acquired because the Seahawks desperately needed a running back.
headline: Agent Confirms Seahawks Star Marshawn Lynch Plans to Retire

text: There's been talk all season of the potential 1 vs. 2 matchup in South Carolina on Monday night. Now, it's finally here with No. 1 UConn visiting the second-ranked Gamecocks.
headline: UConn and South Carolina Set for 1 vs 2 Showdown

text: The mosquitoes that spread the Zika virus are among the hardest species to fight because they live and breed in tub drains, dog bowls, buckets, flower pots and other spots where water collects inside the houses and yards of the people they bite, insect experts noted Monday.
headline: Living With People They Bite, Zika Mosquitoes Hard to Fight

text: One lawsuit seeks to replace lead-leaching water lines at no cost to customers. Another seeks money for thousands of Flint residents who unwittingly drank toxic water. A third complaint has been filed on behalf of people with Legionnaires' disease.
headline: Lead Contamination of Flint Water Draws Multiple Lawsuits

text: BERLIN - Tickets for the 66th Berlinale festival have gone on sale with movie fans particularly keen to see the opening night's film "Hail, Caesar!".
headline: Berlinale Festival Tickets Go on Sale

text: The Pentagon confirmed on Monday that it will start formal talks with South Korea on deploying an advanced missile defense system to South Korea to counter the growing threat of North Korea's weapons capabilities after its rocket launch this weekend.
headline: U.S., South Korea to Discuss Deploying Advanced Missile Defense System

text: The Russian Defense Ministry says one of its helicopters has crashed in northwestern Russia, killing its entire crew of four.
headline: 4 Crew Dead in Russian Military Helicopter Crash

text: The French data protection authority on Monday gave Facebook three months to stop tracking non-users' web activity without their consent and ordered the social network to stop some transfers of personal data to the United States.
headline: French Data Privacy Regulator Cracks Down on Facebook

text: Allies of the United States agree that an "impactful response" is needed following a rocket launch in North Korea over the weekend, White House spokesman Josh Earnest said on Monday.
headline: White House: 'Impactful Response' Needed on North Korea

text: A Wisconsin couple allowed their 9-year-old daughter to drive them and their 11-month-old baby because they were too drunk to do so themselves, according to Polk County Circuit Court records.
headline: Wisconsin Couple, Too Drunk to Drive, Give Keys to 9-Year-Old: Court

text: Villanova joined an exclusive club Monday. The Wildcats are now among the 57 schools to have been ranked No. 1 in The Associated Press college basketball poll.
headline: Villanova Latest No. 1 in AP Poll; 6th Top Team This Season

text: Chelsea's French defender Kurt Zouma will be out for six months  after surgery on a knee injury suffered at the weekend, the Premier League champions said on Monday.
headline: Chelsea's Zouma Faces Six Months Out After Knee Surgery

text: Four people were killed when a Mi-8 helicopter owned by the Russian Defense Ministry crashed on Monday in the Pskov region of northwest Russia, local news agencies reported, quoting the ministry.
headline: Four Killed in Crash of Russian Military Helicopter

text: The Pentagon on Monday praised Canada's decision to triple the number of troops training Kurdish forces in Iraq.
headline: Pentagon Praises Canada for Boosting Training Troops in Iraq

text: The U.S. House Committee on Natural Resources is to hold a hearing on Puerto Rico on Feb. 25, it said in a statement, as Congress tries to come up with a solution for the debt-ridden U.S. territory.
headline: House Committee to Hold Puerto Rico Hearing Feb. 25

text: Villanova is No. 1 in The Associated Press college basketball poll for the first time.
headline: Villanova No. 1 in AP College Hoops Poll for First Time

text: Weakness in emerging market economies risks triggering further depreciation of their currencies and will be addressed in a coordinated manner, ECB Executive Board member Benoit Coeure said on Monday.
headline: ECB's Coeure Sees G20 Coordination Emerging Market Currencies

text: Police in Tanzania say they are holding a total of nine suspects over the killing of a British helicopter pilot who was on an anti-poaching mission.
headline: Tanzania Arrests More Suspects in Slaying of British Pilot

text: Consumer review website operator Yelp Inc reported a smaller-than-expected loss on Monday, but its shares slumped 11 percent, swept up in a broader selloff in the technology sector coupled with a weak adjusted EBITDA forecast.
headline: Yelp Posts Smaller-Than-Expected Loss; CFO to Step Down

text: LafargeHolcim has received a revised order from the Competition Commission of India (CCI) to divest its interest in Lafarge India, including three cement plants and two grinding stations with total annual capacity of 11 million tons, it said.
headline: LafargeHolcim Receives Revised Divestment Order From India

text: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said on Monday it may be possible to hold talks over the next few weeks on ending the conflict in Yemen.
headline: Kerry Hopes for Talks in Weeks on Ending Yemen Conflict

text: Authorities have closed trails at Southern California's Mount Baldy following the death of the second hiker in less than a week.
headline: Trails Closed After 2nd Mount Baldy Death in a Week

text: Britain's Rugeley coal plant will close this summer due to worsening market conditions for coal generation, with the potential loss of 150 jobs, operator Engie said on Monday.
headline: Britain's Rugeley Coal Plant to Close This Summer-Engie

text: Mazda is recalling some SUVs because the fuel filler pipe can rupture in a rear crash and cause a gas leak and possible fire.
headline: Mazda Recalls SUVs Due to Risk of Fuel Filler Pipe Ruptures

text: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan threatened in November to flood Europe with migrants if European Union leaders did not offer him a better deal to help manage the Middle East refugee crisis, a Greek news website said on Monday.
headline: Turkey's Erdogan Threatened to Flood Europe With Migrants: Greek Website

text: The French state said on Monday it could acquire more shares in Alstom if it so wished from Bouygues after reaching a deal with the French construction group.
headline: French State Says Can Buy More Alstom Shares

text: Riot police broke up a demonstration by holders of foreign currency mortgages and detained around 10 people after protesters briefly blocked the road in front of the country's central bank in Moscow, a Reuters witness said on Monday.
headline: Riot Police Detain Forex Mortgage Protesters in Moscow

text: Here's the latest on the hearing for Adnan Syed, the convicted killer at the center of the "Serial" podcast who is asking a judge for a new trial. The hearing began last Wednesday and is now in its fourth day.
headline: The Latest: State, Defense Rest at Hearing for 'Serial' Case

text: U.S. health officials said on Monday that a widespread vaccine to combat the Zika virus will likely not be available for years.
headline: U.S. Health Official: Widespread Zika Vaccine Not Likely to Be Available for Years

text: A porn actress has dropped her $500,000 assault lawsuit against reality TV personality Josh Duggar amid evidence that her claims were fabricated.
headline: Porn Actress Drops $500K Assault Lawsuit Against Josh Duggar

text: A federal judge on Monday signed off on an agreement between Arizona and an inmate to end a claim of racial segregation in the state's 10 prisons.
headline: Judge Adopts Deal Involving Racial Claim at Arizona Prisons

text: U.S. President Barack Obama and Italian President Sergio Mattarella met on Monday in the White House and discussed efforts to work together to combat the Islamic State in Libya.
headline: Obama, Italy's Mattarella Discuss Fight Against Islamic State in Libya

text: Buffalo Bills running back LeSean McCoy is under investigation over a Philadelphia nightclub brawl early Sunday that left two off-duty police officers injured, one with a broken nose and broken ribs and the other with a possible skull fracture.
headline: LeSean McCoy Investigated Over Fight With Off-Duty Cops

text: Saudi Arabia's offer to send troops to fight Islamic State in Syria is as much about the kingdom's growing determination to flex its military might as it is about answering U.S. calls for more help from its allies in the Middle East.
headline: Saudi Offer to Send Troops to Syria Comes With Uncertainty

text: Just because the U.S. economic recovery is nearly seven years along is no reason to think that the nation is due for a recession, according to a study published Monday by the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank.
headline: Economic Expansions Don't Die of Old Age: Fed Study

text: The struggling New York Knicks have fired head coach Derek Fisher less than two years after he was brought in to help turn around the once-proud franchise, the National Basketball Association team said on Monday.
headline: Struggling Knicks Fire Coach Fisher in Second Season

text: Daniel Gerson, who co-wrote several Walt Disney animated films including "Monsters, Inc." and "Big Hero 6," has died. He was 49.
headline: Gerson, Scribe of 'Monsters, Inc.,' 'Big Hero 6' Dies at 49

text: Zurich police used tear gas and rubber bullets to try to break up a group of around 100 Kurdish activists holding an unauthorized demonstration outside the Turkish consulate in Switzerland's financial capital on Monday.
headline: Swiss Use Tear Gas, Rubber Bullets to Break Up Kurdish Rally

text: For more than a year after an officer shot and killed a black teen named Laquan McDonald, the Chicago Police Department had video footage that raised serious doubts about whether other officers at the scene tried in their reports to cover up what prosecutors now contend was murder.
headline: Chicago Teen's Death Shines Light on Police Code of Silence

text: Several people quarantined in Connecticut after returning from West Africa during the Ebola epidemic in 2014 were essentially imprisoned illegally under a state policy based on politics, not science, according to a lawsuit they filed on Monday.
headline: Governor, Health Officials Sued Over Ebola Quarantines

text: President Barack Obama and Italian President Sergio Mattarella met Monday to discuss efforts to fight the spread of the Islamic State in Libya, where the extremist group is capitalizing on political instability to increase its influence.
headline: Obama Says the US and Italy Are Working Together in Libya

text: The Obama administration is taking new steps to protect students amid increased scrutiny of for-profit colleges and other schools.
headline: Gov't Creates New Student Aid Enforcement Office

text: The Golden Age of Online Television may be in peril.
headline: TV Producers May Start Making You Wait for New Shows Online

text: The secretary-general of the Swedish panel that awards the Nobel medicine prize has resigned because of an investigation into disputed stem-cell scientist Paolo Macchiarini.
headline: Nobel Medicine Prize Panel Official Resigns Over Inquiry

text: India's government has essentially banned a Facebook program that sought to connect with low-income residents by offering free access to a limited version of the social network and other Internet services.
headline: India Internet Ruling Blocks Facebook 'Free Basics' Program

text: Israel's government on Monday temporarily suspended from parliamentary meetings three Arab lawmakers who met with families of Palestinians who carried out deadly attacks.
headline: Israeli Parliament Suspends Arab MPs Who Met Attackers' Kin

text: One evening in September 2014, Mariana Yanez left her home in this crime-plagued Mexico City suburb saying she was going to make some photocopies. Then she vanished.
headline: Pope's Visit to Violent Mexican City Highlights Broader Ills

text: Two guns were used in a shooting that killed two men and injured four other people after a Mardi Gras parade in Mississippi, but investigators don't know how many people fired them, the police chief said Monday.
headline: Police: 2 Guns in Miss Shooting That Killed 2, Wounded 4

text: Egypt has denied the police had anything to do with the brutal killing of an Italian student whose body was found on the outskirts of Cairo bearing signs of torture.
headline: Egypt Insists Italian Student's Slaying Was 'Criminal'

text: Human remains found at several locations in northern Ohio over the weekend are believed to be those of one woman who was last seen in July, police said.
headline: Police: Remains of Ohio Woman Found at Several Locations

text: Iran plans to turn itself into a major food exporter, hoping the lifting of sanctions will boost international trade and allow investment in the agricultural sector, an official in Iran's state grain buying agency said.
headline: Iran Hopes for Agricultural Boom Post-Sanctions

text: Share prices for Chesapeake Energy stock were down more than 50 percent for a time Monday after a news report said the Oklahoma City-based company had brought on attorneys who help companies restructure their debt, but rebounded after the natural gas producer told investors that it was not planning to file for bankruptcy protection.
headline: Chesapeake Stock Tumbles, Rises After Investors Spooked

text: President Barack Obama will ask the U.S. Congress for more than $1.8 billion (£1.2 billion) in emergency funds to fight Zika at home and abroad and pursue a vaccine, the White House said on Monday, but Obama also said there was no reason to panic over the mosquito-borne virus.
headline: Obama Seeks Funds to Fight Zika; Sees No Cause for Panic

text: The second-seeded Cilic of Croatia had 10 aces in a 7-6 (5), 6-4 win against Denis Istomin of Uzbekistan in the first round of the World Tennis Tournament on Monday.
headline: 2nd-Seeded Cilic and Dodig Advance to 2nd Round in Rotterdam

text: More than 30 years ago, Donald Trump bought a franchise in the upstart United States Football League. He then led his fellow owners to sue the NFL in a high-stakes antitrust case.
headline: How Donald Trump, With Pizazz and Bluster, Took on the NFL

text: Rally Sweden organisers have axed eight of the event's 21 scheduled stages after unusually warm weather threatened to force the cancellation of the second round of the world championship this weekend.
headline: Swedish Organisers Cut Stages After Cancellation Fears

text: Detectives say a Pennsylvania inmate being hauled off to solitary confinement grabbed a guard's stun gun and fired, injuring four correctional officers.
headline: Detectives: Inmate Grabs Guard's Stun Gun and Fires, Hurts 4

text: The world's largest cigar maker, Scandinavian Tobacco Group (STG), has narrowed the price range for its initial public offering (IPO) to 99-103 Danish crowns ($14.79-$15.38) per share, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday.
headline: Cigar Maker STG Narrows Range of Its IPO-Source

text: Don McLean's attorney says the singer has entered a not-guilty plea to a domestic violence charge in writing and will not appear in court later this month.
headline: Don McLean Pleads Not Guilty to Domestic Violence Charge

text: Canada's prime minister on Monday announced that the country will end airstrikes against the Islamic State group in Syria and Iraq by Feb. 22, saying that "the people terrorized by ISIL every day don't need our vengeance, they need our help."
headline: Canada to End Airstrikes Against Islamic State Group Shortly

text: Forces allied to Libya's eastern government carried out air strikes on Islamic State militant areas of Derna city, but an aircraft later crashed because of mechanical failure, a spokesman said on Monday.
headline: Libya Forces Say Conduct Strikes on Islamic State in Derna, Plane Crashes

text: When the emergency room fills up — whether it's a big accident, flu season or a stroke of misfortune — Brooklyn nurse Rose Green says she can find herself sprinting from room to room, trying to keep ahead of the whims of calamity.
headline: Citing Huge Patient Load, NY Nurses Seek Rules on Staffing

text: The Hillary Clinton campaign volunteers made their pitch to a postal worker who said he favored her Democratic rival, Bernie Sanders.
headline: Clinton's Donors Trade Buck-Raising for Door-Knocking in NH

text: Technology shares with lofty valuations, including those of midcap data analytics company Tableau Software Inc and Internet giant Facebook Inc, extended their losses on Monday following a gutting selloff in the previous session.
headline: Tech Stocks Extend Losses, Valuations Dented

text: The entertainer Flavor Flav pleaded no contest Monday to misdemeanor driving under the influence in Las Vegas, marking the second plea in two weeks involving similar charges in Nevada.
headline: Flavor Flav Pleads No Contest to DUI Charge in Las Vegas

text: Shares in Barclays resumed trading on Monday, having briefly been suspended due to outsized moves.
headline: Barclays Shares Resume After Volatility Triggers Suspension

text: Leicester visited Manchester City and came away with a 3-1 win over the high-priced club to stay in first place.
headline: A Sly Fox Keeps Improving Leicester's Odds

text: At the opening weekend of the 2016 Six Nations, it was the drop goals that did not happen that proved decisive in all three matches.
headline: Missed Drop Goals Crucial to Two Six Nations Losses

text: Results of the sales of Impressionist, modern and Surrealist art at Sotheby's and Christie's in London were considerably lower than they were last February.
headline: Early Inklings of an Art Market Chill

text: Egyptian Interior Minister Magdi Abdel Ghaffar said on Monday he rejected media accusations that security forces were behind the killing of an Italian student who was found dead on a Cairo roadside with signs of torture on his body.
headline: Egypt Rejects Media Accusations Security Forces Behind Killing of Italian Student

text: It's their Everest. Their firewall. Their lifeboat in a frozen Atlantic.
headline: For the Clintons, New Hampshire Is the State of 2nd Chances

text: Azize Calis is pleading for peace.
headline: Displaced by Fighting, Kurdish Residents Call for Peace

text: As some cities make the decision to shed Confederate monuments, some Alabama lawmakers want to prohibit those removals unless legislators say it is OK.
headline: Bill Would Stop Removal of Confederate, Historic Markers

text: Volkswagen says its quality control chief is leaving the company.
headline: Quality Control Chief Leaves Scandal-Hit Volkswagen

text: Qatar may create special courts during the 2022 soccer World Cup to deal quickly and "very gently" with alcohol-consuming fans who break the law in a conservative Muslim state where public drunkenness is prohibited, a Qatari official said on Monday.
headline: Qatar Considering Special Courts for World Cup Offenders

text: Derek Fisher had just finished a long playing career when Phil Jackson picked him to coach the New York Knicks. Just 1 1/2 seasons later, Jackson decided he needed someone else.
headline: Knicks Fire Coach Derek Fisher; Rambis Gets Interim Job

text: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Monday Canada would pull out six jets that have been bombing targets in Iraq and Syria, ending a controversial combat role in the fight against Islamic State.
headline: Canada to End Bombing Missions in Iraq and Syria

text: Canada's Amaya Inc, operator of online gambling website PokerStars, said on Monday that a special committee of its board has tapped Barclays to review an expected all-cash offer from its Chief Executive David Baazov.
headline: Amaya Taps Barclays to Review Pending Buyout Proposal From CEO

text: British prosecutors have delayed the start of their third Libor trial after new information was provided by Barclays, the former employer of the latest group of traders charged with conspiracy to manipulate financial benchmark interest rates.
headline: UK Delays Libor Trial of Former Barclays Traders

text: The Latest on the trial of a New York City police officer charged in the deadly shooting of an unarmed man (all times local):
headline: The Latest: Mother of Man Killed by NYPD Officer Speaks Out

text: An increasingly important gauge of U.S. inflation tumbled last month to its lowest level since the Federal Reserve Bank of New York began the survey in mid-2013, in what could be taken as another warning bell for the U.S. central bank.
headline: U.S. Inflation Survey Tumbles in Red Flag for Fed

text: Baltimore prosecutors have asked a judge to delay the trials of three police officers charged in the Freddie Gray case until appellate courts decide if another officer awaiting retrial on related charges can be compelled to testify against them.
headline: State Seeks Delay in 3 Freddie Gray Trials, Pending Appeals

text: The leader of Belarus says Russia has promised to offer financial assistance to his nation.
headline: Belarusian Leader Says Russia Will Offer Bailout

text: Somewhere in the Dallas area, a retired man sitting in a home office is making social media videos backing Japanese right-wing views that have made him a celebrity among hawks in the Asian country.
headline: Obscure at Home,' Texas Daddy' Is a Right-Wing Darling in Japan

text: Volkswagen's former head of group quality control Frank Tuch has left the carmaker as chief executive Matthias Mueller overhauls senior management positions following the emissions test-rigging scandal.
headline: VW's Former Quality Chief Quits as CEO Pushes Overhaul

text: Star Cuban infielder Yulieski Gourriel and his younger brother slipped away from their hotel in the Dominican Republic early Monday in an apparent effort to launch careers in Major League Baseball.
headline: Top Cuban Player Slips Away With Brother to Join US Majors

text: Chesapeake Energy, the No. 2 U.S. natural gas producer, said on Monday it had no plans to file for bankruptcy, after sources told Reuters the company had asked its longtime counsel to look at restructuring options.
headline: Chesapeake Moves to Quash Bankruptcy Fears as Shares Plunge

text: Things looked so clear back in mid-December. The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate from record lows, and it signaled the likelihood of four more hikes in 2016.
headline: Yellen Will Testify Amid Predictions of Slower Rate Hikes

text: Iran will increase its share of the global oil market gradually, in order to avoid price volatility, RIA news agency quoted Iran's envoy to Moscow as saying on Monday.
headline: Iran's Envoy to Russia Says Tehran Will Raise Oil Market Share Gradually-RIA

text: The Latest on a cruise ship that was damaged in bad weather in the Atlantic Ocean (all times local):
headline: The Latest: Weather Forecast Called for Storm-Force Winds

text: With 30-second Super Bowl ads costing up to $5 million, it's a huge gamble to advertise. As the Denver Broncos defeated the Carolina Panthers, there were winners and losers off the field, too. Here are the advertisers whose gamble paid off, and those who dropped the ball.
headline: Audi Tearjerker,' Puppymonkeybaby' Among Super Bowl Winners

text: Turkey and Germany plan to seek help from NATO allies in monitoring the flow of migrants from Syria trying to get to Europe across the Aegean Sea, Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said on Monday.
headline: Turkey, Germany to Seek NATO Help Monitoring Migrant Flow From Syria

text: Margaret Forster, the author of "Georgy Girl" and more than 20 other novels, has died in London after suffering from cancer in the back and spine. She was 77.
headline: 'Georgy Girl' Author Margaret Forster, 77, Dies of Cancer

text: Uganda has bought anti-riot gear ahead of a Feb. 18 election in a move which police say will bolster security during voting but which critics say aims to intimidate opponents of President Yoweri Museveni, who is seeking to extend his 30-year rule.
headline: Uganda Police Buy Anti-Riot Gear Ahead of Museveni's Re-election Bid

text: Super Bowl 50 was the third most-watched Super Bowl in U.S. history with 111.9 million Americans watching the game on television, ratings data showed on Monday.
headline: Nearly 112 Million Watch Super Bowl 50 on TV, Below Record

text: The strongman leader of Russia's Chechen republic says special operation units from his region have infiltrated the Islamic State group.
headline: Chechen Special Ops in Syria Says Republic's Leader

text: Dubai's ruler said Monday the United Arab Emirates will privatize some government services in the oil-rich country, as well as create a state minister position devoted to ensuring the happiness of its citizens.
headline: Dubai Ruler Says Emirates to Privatize Government Services

text: Ian Mader, a veteran foreign correspondent with a reputation for breaking news and challenging reporters, has been named The Associated Press Florida news editor based in Miami.
headline: Ian Mader Named AP's News Editor in Florida

text: A winter storm was expected to bring more than a foot (30 cm) of snow and howling winds to parts of southern New England on Monday, closing schools and government offices, snarling travel and flooding low-lying coastal areas.
headline: Winter Storm Pounds Southern New England, Snarling Travel

text: The World Health Organization needs urgent reform to boost its ability to respond to crises, and failure to act now could cost thousands of lives, according to an advance copy of a high-level U.N. report.
headline: Lives at Risk Unless WHO Reforms, U.N. Report Says

text: When he was not being a string-shredding, amp-blasting guitar hero, Jimi Hendrix liked nothing better than to sit at home drinking tea and watching the British soap opera "Coronation Street."
headline: Fans Can Have Hendrix Experience at Guitarist's London Home

text: The United Arab Emirates plans to outsource most government tasks to the private sector and cut the number of ministries, Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum said on Monday.
headline: UAE Plans to Trim Ministries, Outsource Most Government Services: PM

text: President Vladimir Putin has hosted the ruler of Bahrain for talks focused on the Syrian crisis and economic cooperation.
headline: King of Bahrain in Russia for Talks With Putin

text: Former England batsman Kevin Pietersen will not be recalled for this year's World Twenty20 in India, captain Eoin Morgan was quoted on Monday as saying.
headline: Pietersen Won't Be Selected for World Twenty20-Morgan

text: When rookie police Officer Peter Liang fired his gun in a pitch-dark public housing stairwell, he at first thought he had hurt nothing but his career. Then he went looking for the bullet and heard someone crying.
headline: Emotional NYC Officer Testifies on Fatal Stairwell Shooting

text: A high-ranking Senate Democrat is scrutinizing links between pharmaceutical companies and government advisers who recently criticized efforts to reduce painkiller prescribing.
headline: Senator Scrutinizes Pharma Links on Government Pain Panel

text: Pfizer Inc, which agreed to buy Allergan Plc for $160 billion last year, unveiled its management line up for the combined company, once the deal closes in the second half of 2016.
headline: Pfizer Unveils Management Line Up for Combined Company

text: Chipotle Mexican Grill closed all of its U.S. restaurants during prime lunchtime hours on Monday to hold staff meetings on food safety guidelines, sparking offers from rivals eager to poach customers of the burrito chain as it recovers from several food-borne outbreaks.
headline: Chipotle Shuts U.S. Stores for Food Safety Meeting, Rivals Pounce

text: Credit Suisse's higher fixed costs are one of several unintended consequences of the new rules governing banker pay. The Swiss bank is shrinking the proportion of annual bonuses it defers to 41 percent, from well over half in 2013. There's a clear rationale: boss Tidjane Thiam is trying to cut expenses, yet he can barely clamp down on pay because of awards made in previous years that keep coming due.
headline: Credit Suisse Chips Away at Bonus Deferral Fetish

text: Disgraced world soccer president Sepp Blatter and the sport's European head, Michel Platini, will be invited to the 2018 World Cup in Russia, Russian Sports Minister Vitaly Mutko said on Monday.
headline: Russia Says Blatter, Platini to Be Invited to World Cup

text: The Obama administration is seeking $250 million in federal funds to help Puerto Rico fight an increase in Zika cases after the governor declared a public health emergency.
headline: Obama Seeks $250M to Help Puerto Rico Fight Zika

text: U.S. President Barack Obama will meet with Jordan's King Abdullah at the White House on Feb. 24, the White House said on Monday.
headline: Obama to Meet With Jordan's King Abdullah: White House

text: New rules requiring multinational corporations to reveal tax and financial data to authorities in all EU countries where they operate may be agreed by the bloc's states as soon as March, EU diplomats said on Monday.
headline: EU Aims at Deal on Multinationals' Tax Disclosures in March

text: An FBI agent on Monday accused lawyers for a convicted murderer of manipulating cell phone records in their bid to win a retrial for the Maryland slaying made famous by the podcast "Serial."
headline: FBI Agent Says Evidence Manipulated in Baltimore 'Serial' Hearing

text: Five Iranian-American groups wrote to U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry last week, urging him to work for the release of an Iranian-American businessman who has been detained in Iran since October.
headline: Groups Urge Kerry to Work for Release of U.S. Businessman Held in Iran

text: Britain's cost watchdog has recommended that patients with high cholesterol should not get Sanofi and Regeneron's new cholesterol-lowering injection Praluent, although Amgen's similar drug Repatha will be available.
headline: UK Cost Agency Rebuffs Sanofi Cholesterol Drug but Backs Amgen's

text: Authorities say a Pennsylvania man stole several police badges while he was being held for questioning in a domestic dispute.
headline: Man Accused of Stealing Police Badges While Being Questioned

text: International investigators say several thousands of detainees have been executed, beaten to death or otherwise left to die during Syria's civil war, in policies that appear to amount to extermination under international law.
headline: UN Panel Documents 'Extermination' of Detainees in Syria

text: At least nine civilians and 16 rebel fighters have been killed as security forces battle militants of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) in Turkey's mainly Kurdish southeast, the army and the region's main political party said on Monday.
headline: Tens Killed in Clashes in Turkey's Kurdish Southeast

text: A special investigation team set up in Pakistan to probe a  deadly assault on an Indian air base last month found no evidence implicating the leader of the group India blamed for the attack, Pakistani security officials said on Monday.
headline: Pakistan Probe: No Evidence Links Militant Group to Indian Air Base Attack-Officials

text: Wall Street villains are having their big moment on both television and the big screen.
headline: Wall St. Crooks Get a Screen Test – and This Time Pull in Big Audiences

text: As the number of Syrian refugees now amassing on the Turkish border swells into the tens of thousands, Ankara's long-standing open door to migrants may be closing.
headline: Faced With New Influx, Turkey's Open Door for Migrants May Be Closing

text: Andrew Keenan-Bolger isn't tapping into his vulnerable side for his next Broadway role. He's trying to be utterly fearless.
headline: Broadway's 'Tuck Everlasting' Hopes for Eternal Experience

text: Liverpool manager Juergen Klopp will return to the dugout for Tuesday's FA Cup fourth-round replay at West Ham United after missing the draw with Sunderland due to illness and he hopes to be joined by Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho.
headline: Klopp, Sturridge, Coutinho Return for Liverpool

text: United Nations war crimes investigators have provided judicial assistance to various countries in response to 15 requests for information on foreign fighters in Syria, investigator Carla del Ponte said on Monday.
headline: U.N. War Crimes Team Has Shared Files on Foreign Fighters in Syria

text: Wal-Mart Stores Inc's top retailing expert Andy Murray has been sent over to its British supermarkets operator Asda to try to reverse a decline in sales and loss of market share to fast-growing discount rivals.
headline: Wal-Mart Retailing Expert Andy Murray Moves to UK Arm Asda

text: 2016 could be the year of the sugar tax, as several large nations consider levies on sweetened food and drinks to battle obesity and fatten government coffers.
headline: For Sugar Tax Supporters, 2016 May Be the Sweet Spot

text: Actress Lily James is confident Jane Austen fans will warm to  "Pride and Prejudice and Zombies", a gory variation on the classic English novel, despite her own initial reservations about the project.
headline: Lily James Promises Zombie Treat for Jane Austen Fans

text: President Vladimir Putin has scrambled thousands of troops and hundreds of warplanes across southwestern Russia for large-scale military drills intended to test the troops' readiness amid continuing tensions with the West.
headline: Russian Troops Put on High Alert as Part of Massive Drills

text: A winter storm with hurricane-force winds and huge waves battered Britain's coastline Monday, cutting power to thousands and disrupting travel across the country.
headline: Storm Imogen Lashes Britain With Wind, Huge Waves

text: A Philippine rebel leader said Monday that Congress' failure to pass a Muslim autonomy bill as part of a new peace pact would delay a program to disarm thousands of guerrillas in the country's south.
headline: Philippine Autonomy Delay Stalls Disarming of Muslim Rebels

text: A Royal Caribbean cruise ship ran into high winds and rough seas in the Atlantic Ocean on Sunday, forcing frightened passengers into their cabins overnight as their belongings flew about, waves rose as high as 30 feet, and winds howled outside. The cruise line says that although no one was injured and the ship suffered only minor damage, it's turning around and sailing back to its home port in New Jersey.
headline: Cruise Ship That Sailed in Storm Headed Back to Home Port

text: A police vehicle carrying North Carolina Governor Pat McCrory was involved in a minor traffic accident after leaving the Super Bowl in California, the governor's office said on Monday.
headline: North Carolina Governor in Minor Traffic Accident After Super Bowl

text: The Latest on the snowstorm that's moving into the Northeast (all times local):
headline: The Latest: 30 of 70 on Bus That Crashed in Snow Were Hurt

text: Ireland's junior government party wants to more than treble a levy on the country's banks if it is re-elected this month, the Labour Party said on Monday, splitting from its senior partner which would maintain the current level.
headline: Irish Junior Coalition Party Would More Than Treble Bank Levy

text: Dozens of armed security forces descended on the Quranic school at night, arresting an imam suspected of having links to Islamic extremists in Nigeria.
headline: Senegal Fears Extremism Amid Imam Arrests, Regional Attacks

text: Greece said on Monday it would have migrant registration centers             running by next week, under pressure from EU partners threatening to sideline it from passport-free travel unless it does more to contain refugees.
headline: Greece Says Will Have Refugee Centers Open by Feb. 15 Deadline

text: Clashes have erupted outside the Turkish Embassy in Paris after police moved in to disperse a demonstration by Kurdish political activists.
headline: Kurdish Protest Against Turkey Turns Violent in Paris

text: Prosecutors say a woman and man accused of robbing jewelry stores across the South have been indicted by a federal grand jury in northern Florida.
headline: Grand Jury Indicts Duo Accused of Southern Jewelry Robberies

text: A Detroit-area man who had said he walked 21 miles a day to and from work is finding life is much easier about a year after receiving a new car and a windfall of donations, but the downside to that generosity is that he has put on weight.
headline: Man Who Walked Miles to Work Settles Into New Life

text: An explosion damaged a car in the Saudi capital Riyadh on Monday, the Saudi Press Agency reported, an incident the Islamic State militant group said was caused by a bomb one of its members had affixed to the vehicle.
headline: Islamic State Claims Car Bomb Blast in Saudi Capital

text: Electronic gear shifters on some newer Fiat Chrysler SUVs and cars are so confusing that drivers have exited the vehicles with the engines running and while they are still in gear, causing crashes and serious injuries, U.S. safety investigators have determined.
headline: Feds Find Fiat Chrysler Gear Shifters Can Confuse Drivers

text: Few events have ever garnered as much discussion as the assassination of President John F. Kennedy at Dealey Plaza in Dallas on a Friday afternoon in November 1963, which changed the nation forever.
headline: Hulu's Time-Travel Drama '11.22.63' Examines America's Ugly Scars

text: In this photo by Rajesh Kumar Singh, police on horses patrol as thousands of Hindus perform rituals at the Sangam, the confluence of the Ganges, Yamuna, and the mythical Saraswati rivers, during the Magh Mela in Allahabad, India. Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims will bathe in the confluence during the annual festival, hoping to wash away their sins. Monday is the morning of the new moon, or "Mauni Amavasya," the most auspicious and most popular day for the ritual.
headline: Image of Asia: On Patrol at Holy Confluence of Indian Rivers

text: The United States and its allies conducted ten strikes against Islamic State militants in Iraq and Syria on Sunday, the Combined Joint Task Force leading the operations said in a statement released on Monday.
headline: U.S.-Led Coalition Targets ISIS With 10 Air Strikes in Syria, Iraq

text: South Africa's Illovo Sugar said on Monday it has received a non-binding expression of interest from its largest shareholder Associated British Foods in buying the rest of the company.
headline: Associated British Foods Offers to Buy South Africa's Illovo Sugar

text: Israel plans to increase the number of entry permits it grants to Palestinian workers, Palestinian and Israeli sources said on Monday, in a drive to ease economic hardship that has contributed to a wave of Palestinian attacks.
headline: Israel Eyes More Entry Permits to Palestinian Workers to Douse Tensions

text: Italy kept pressure on Egypt Monday to cooperate in finding who tortured and murdered an Italian student doing research in Cairo, insisting it wouldn't accept convenient answers in the case.
headline: Italy Urges Egypt to Help Find Who Tortured, Killed Student

text: Top Academy Award nominees will have a politically charged gift in their swag bag this year - a luxury trip to Israel paid for in part by a government that hopes such celebrity junkets will offset news coverage of the country's troubles.
headline: Israel Tries to Bolster Its Image via Oscars 'Swag Bag'

text: Greece's lenders still need to be persuaded that Athens can plug a bigger than expected fiscal gap when talks on reforms needed under an international bailout resume next week, the finance minister said on Monday.
headline: Greece Expects Bailout Review to Resume Next Week-Minister

text: A prominent Democratic donor worried about the party's chances of winning the presidency emailed dozens of fans of Vice President Joe Biden on Friday, urging them to remain prepared to donate if Biden jumps into the race.
headline: Democratic Donor Contacts Biden Allies About Possible Run

text: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has erased Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's wide lead for the Democratic presidential nomination since the start of year, putting the two in a dead heat nationally, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll.
headline: Exclusive: Presidential Hopefuls Sanders, Clinton in Dead Heat-Reuters/Ipsos Poll

text: A former budget minister who championed France's campaign against tax dodgers went on trial on Monday three years after he was forced to quit over the discovery that he owned a secret bank account abroad.
headline: Former French Budget Minister Goes on Trial for Tax Evasion

text: President Barack Obama is set on Tuesday to unveil his budget proposal for fiscal year 2017, his final year in office.
headline: Factbox: What Will Be in Obama's Final Budget Proposal?

text: U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton said during a student town hall on Saturday that student loan servicer Navient Corp has been "misleading people" and "doing some really terrible things."
headline: Clinton Slams Student Loan Servicer Navient as Misleading

text: Most of Britain's proposals for European Union reform are acceptable but more talks are needed on some, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban said on Monday after meeting Polish premier Beata Szydlo in Budapest.
headline: Hungary PM Says More Talks Needed on Some of Britain's EU Reform Ideas

text: An Alabama airport has added a plaque to remember a Kansas boy who died when he was hit by a falling flight information sign.
headline: Plaque Honors Kansas Boy Who Died at Alabama Airport

text: A Spanish man who is the prime suspect in the gruesome murder of a fellow Spaniard was in Thai custody Monday after being arrested in Cambodia, where he fled after the victim's dismembered body was recovered over several days from Bangkok's Chao Phraya River.
headline: Suspect in Murder of Dismembered Spaniard in Thai Custody

text: Expecting to write a ticket for speeding, an Alabama State Trooper ended up helping a woman give birth.
headline: Alabama Trooper Stops Speeders, Delivers Baby Instead

text: Police in the Maldives arrested a judge and former prosecutor general over their alleged involvement in a fraudulent court order to arrest President Abdulla Yameen, a presidential spokesman said on Monday.
headline: Maldives Arrests Judge, Former Legal Official Over Court Order

text: India introduced rules on Monday to prevent Internet service providers from having different pricing policies for accessing different parts of the Web, in a setback to Facebook Inc's plan to roll out a pared-back free Internet service to the masses.
headline: India Introduces Net Neutrality Rules Barring Facebook's Free Internet

text: A bill that opponents say targets Israeli human rights groups critical of Israel's policies towards the Palestinians won initial approval in parliament on Monday with the support of  right-wing parties.
headline: Israel NGO Bill, Seen as Targeting Left-Wing Groups, Crosses First Hurdle

text: Pope Francis' sex-abuse commission stressed Monday that its sole purpose is to propose initiatives to protect children from pedophiles, after it effectively suspended a member who advocated a more activist role.
headline: Vatican Stresses Policy Role of Sex Committee After Ouster

text: The Netherlands has stepped up the monitoring of traffic crossing its frontiers, a government minister said on Monday, as countries across Europe move to tighten border controls in response to an unprecedented migration crisis.
headline: Dutch Step Up Border Controls as Migrant Flows Continue

text: An Irish Republican Army faction claimed responsibility Monday for killing a reputed member of a drug-dealing gang in a machine gun attack on a Dublin boxing event — and threatened to kill more criminal rivals as part of a long-running underworld feud.
headline: IRA Faction Says It Attacked Dublin Boxing Event, Killed Man

text: Leicester City fan Leigh Herbert will pocket a cool 25,000 pounds if his team complete their fairytale run and win the Premier League title.
headline: Fan Eyes Large Windfall if Leicester Complete Fairytale

text: The Latest on the race for the White House with one day to go until the New Hampshire primary (all times local):
headline: The Latest: Clinton Vows to 'Make a Difference' Every Day

text: U.S. President Barack Obama said he was concerned but not surprised about North Korea's rocket launch over the weekend, saying his administration is pressing China and working with South Korea to pressure North Korea's regime and block its efforts.
headline: Obama: North Korea Rocket Launch Concerning but Not a Surprise

text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel criticized Russia on Monday for bombings in Syria that have forced tens of thousands of civilians to flee, suggesting they were in violation of a U.N. Security Council resolution that Moscow signed in December.
headline: Merkel Criticizes Russia Over Syria Bombing That Forces Thousands to Flee

text: Thousands of refugees could flock to Britain from France if voters decide to leave the European Union, a spokesman for David Cameron said on Monday, underlining the prime minister's stance that an exit would hurt security.
headline: Thousands of Refugees May Enter Britain if It Leaves EU: Cameron

text: A 93-year-old World War II veteran is embarking on a 10,500-mile journey to Australia to visit his wartime girlfriend after more than 70 years apart.
headline: WWII Vet Begins Journey to Reunite With Wartime Girlfriend

text: A South African university suspended two white students for painting their faces in what it called a "blackface" incident deemed to be racially offensive. One of the students, however, said they were dressing as purple space aliens for a party with a galactic theme.
headline: South African University Suspends 2 in Costume Outcry

text: Police in Saudi Arabia say an explosion damaged cars in the capital, Riyadh, but did not wound anyone.
headline: Saudi Police: No Injuries in Blast in Capital

text: Nepal’s ethnic minority groups lifted a four-month-old blockade along a major trading point with India on Monday, saying it didn't want ordinary people to suffer anymore, but vowed to carry on with its campaign against the new constitution.
headline: Nepal Ethnic Minorities Call Off Blockade Over Charter

text: Philippine President Benigno Aquino on Monday accepted the resignation of foreign minister Albert del Rosario, who helped spearhead the country's vigorous challenge to China's territorial claims in the South China Sea.
headline: Philippines' Foreign Minister Resigns Over Health Issues

text: Detainees held by the Syrian government are being killed on a massive scale amounting to a state policy of "extermination" of the civilian population, a crime against humanity, United Nations investigators said on Monday.
headline: Mass Deaths in Syrian Jails Amount to Crime of 'Extermination'-U.N.

text: President Barack Obama is asking Congress for more than $1.8 billion in emergency funding to fight the Zika virus and the mosquitoes that spread it here and abroad, but says "there shouldn't be a panic on this."
headline: Obama Asking Congress for Emergency Funding to Combat Zika

text: A quarter of a century since Margaret Thatcher was deposed by her own party, Britain's 'Iron Lady' has stirred a row: Would the hero of Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative party have voted to leave the European Union?
headline: From Beyond the Grave,' Iron Lady' Thatcher Haunts Britain's EU Debate

text: Shopping center owner and operator Brixmor Property Group Inc said its CEO and two other top officers resigned after an internal review found that its financial statements were tampered with, sending its shares down as much as 25 percent.
headline: Brixmor's Top Executives Exit After Accounting Review, Shares Plunge

text: President Barack Obama will ask the U.S. Congress for more than $1.8 billion in emergency funds to fight Zika at home and abroad and pursue a vaccine, the White House said on Monday, but he added there is no reason to panic over the mosquito-borne virus.
headline: Obama Seeks Funds to Fight Zika; Sees No Cause for Panic

text: A double-decker bus was blown up on a London bridge on Sunday as part of a stunt for an action thriller movie, but the blast surprised some residents.
headline: Bus Blown Up on London Bridge for Jackie Chan Film

text: Turkey will admit the almost 30,000 people fleeing war-torn Syria who have amassed at the border "when necessary," Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu said, adding Russia's air assault should not be tolerated with the idea that Turkey will accept the refugees.
headline: Turkey Will Take Refugees Fleeing Syrian Forces 'When Necessary': PM

text: The American Legion has asked the campaign of Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders to "cease and desist" from using the organization's emblem in campaign fliers.
headline: Sanders Asked to Drop American Legion Emblem From Campaign

text: Raising taxes is "self defeating" when a country tries to bring down the ratio between its public debt and economic output, according to a research paper published by the European Central Bank on Monday and based on the euro zone's recent history.
headline: Tax Hikes 'Self Defeating' When Trying to Cut Govt Debt-ECB Paper

text: British rock band Coldplay's latest music video has triggered a debate in India over its portrayal of the country with critics accusing its producers of showing stereotypical images of India with Hindu holy men, peacocks and colorful festivals.
headline: Coldplay's Latest Video Criticized for Portrayal of India

text: India said its economy grew 7.3 percent in the last three months of 2015, a rate of expansion that puts the South Asian nation ahead of China's 6.8 percent growth during the same period.
headline: India Says 3Q Growth Faster Than China's at 7.3 Percent

text: Concerns over the Zika virus have not affected ticket sales at LATAM Airlines' TAM Brazilian unit, the regional carrier said on Monday.
headline: LATAM Airlines Says No Brazil Sales Impact Yet From Zika Worries

text: An Australian woman who was freed by al Qaeda after three weeks in captivity said on Monday her husband who was seized with her in Burkina Faso was still alive and she hoped he too would be released soon.
headline: Australian Woman Freed by Al Qaeda Says Her Husband Is Still Alive

text: U.S. stocks dropped on Monday as concern over global growth hit banks and other economically sensitive shares, although a late rally in energy shares left the market well above its lows of the day.
headline: Growth Worries, Rate Hike Uncertainty Pull Wall Street Down

text: France wants new "market regulation measures" to help farmers hurt by low milk and pork prices and has submitted proposals ahead of a meeting of European Union agriculture ministers later this month, Prime Minister Manuel Valls said on Monday.
headline: France Asks EU for 'Market Regulation' to Help Struggling Farmers

text: Members of troubled European industries including steel and aluminium will descend on Brussels in their thousands next Monday to protest against proposed measures to give China greater access to EU markets, and call for action on subsidised Chinese imports.
headline: Thousands to Protest in Brussels Against Relaxing China Trade Defences

text: Indian scientists are investigating whether a man was killed by a meteorite, which if confirmed would be the first recorded death from falling fragments of space rock in almost 200 years.Jayalalithaa Jayaram, the chief minister of Tamil Nadu, has said a bus driver at a college in her state was killed by the meteorite and awarded 100,000 rupees ($1,470) in compensation to his family."A meteorite fell within the college premises," Jayalalithaa said. The man "sustained serious injuries and died while on the way to the hospital".
headline: Scientists Investigate Suspected Meteorite Death in Southern India

text: Greek banks have seen only a trickle of deposit inflows six months after the country clinched a third bailout to stay in the euro zone, and will remain hooked on central bank borrowing for months as confidence has yet to be fully restored.
headline: Trickle of Inflows Point to Long Road to Normality for Greek Banks

text: Apollo Education is being taken private in a $1.1 billion deal by a consortium led by private investment firm The Vistria Group.
headline: Apollo Education to Go Private in $1.1 Billion Deal

text: When executive board members of the World Health Organization sat down for their annual meeting in Geneva in January, many powerful figures spoke forcefully of the need to reform the leading global authority on health and disease.
headline: Special Report-The World Health Organization's Critical Challenge: Healing Itself

text: Italy demanded on Monday that Egypt catch and punish those responsible for the death of a student found tortured by a roadside in Cairo, and the Egyptian government dismissed suggestions its security services could have been involved.
headline: Italy Demands Justice for Slain Student, Egypt Rejects Accusations

text: Irish consumer sentiment surged to a 15-year high in January, a survey showed on Monday, a boost for government parties pinning their re-election hopes on a strong economic recovery.
headline: Irish Consumer Confidence Hits 15-Year High Ahead of Election

text: Irish nationalists opposed to Northern Ireland's peace process have told the BBC they were behind a fatal shooting last Friday at a Dublin hotel, saying it was retaliation for the killing of an ally in 2012.
headline: Dissident Irish Nationalists Claim Fatal Dublin Shooting: BBC

text: Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi is facing criticism after a massive red carpet was laid over public roads for his motorcade during a trip to open a social housing project in a Cairo suburb, where he preached austerity.
headline: Giant Red Carpet for Egypt Leader's Motorcade Sparks Uproar

text: Almost a year has passed since it became legal to smoke, but not sell, marijuana in Washington, D.C., and pot enthusiasts and opponents alike are chafing under a compromise that leaves smokers in a haze over how to obtain their weed.
headline: Pot Fans, Foes Fume as Washington DC Tests Limits of High Life

text: The International Committee of the Red Cross says it has reopened its Gaza office after closing it the previous day in response to repeated attempts by protesters to storm it.
headline: Red Cross in Gaza Reopens Office After Violent Protests

text: A loud, startling sound prompted New York Police Officer Peter Liang to pull the trigger accidentally on his service pistol as he patrolled a pitch-black stairwell, inadvertently shooting dead an unarmed black man, the officer testified on Monday.
headline: New York Policeman Tearfully Describes Shooting Black Man

text: Swansea City must learn to kill off teams by scoring at least two goals, goalkeeper Lukasz Fabianski said as the club seek to keep out of the Premier League's relegation dogfight.
headline: Swansea Must Kill Off Games Not Hold On to Them-Fabianski

text: Employees of U.S. companies seeking to avoid exposure to the Zika virus likely have few legal avenues to either refuse travel to affected areas or sue if they actually become sick from the virus. But it may be a different story if such workers subsequently give birth to Zika-infected babies.
headline: Lawyers See Limited Legal Options for Workers Sent in Zika's Way

text: The top central bankers from France and Germany are joining in an appeal to fix longstanding flaws in the euro currency by more closely integrating their economies and putting more authority over financial policies at the European level.
headline: How to Fix the Euro: Top Bankers Urge Closer Ties

text: The main ethnic group that's been protesting for months over Nepal's new constitution is ending its border blockade and general strike, bringing relief to the Himalayan nation severely short of fuel, medicine and other supplies.
headline: Ethnic Protesters in Nepal Withdraw Border Blockade, Strike

text: Euro 2016 hosts France will play home friendlies against Cameroon and Scotland in the build-up to this year's tournament, the French Football Federation said on Monday.
headline: France to Play Cameroon and Scotland in Euro 2016 Warm-Ups

text: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan threatened in November to flood Europe with migrants if European Union leaders did not offer him a better deal to help manage the Middle East refugee crisis, a Greek news website said on Monday.
headline: Turkey's Erdogan Threatened to Flood Europe With Migrants-Greek Website

text: U.S.-led air strikes have had a substantial impact on the money Islamic State (IS) makes from oil, and have helped force the militant group to cut its fighters' pay by up to 50 percent, a senior U.S official said on Monday.
headline: Air Strikes Help Force ISIS to Halve Fighters' Pay: Glaser

text: At least 12 groups are now working to develop a Zika vaccine and health authorities said on Monday they were working to ensure development proceeded as rapidly as possible.
headline: Race to Fast-Track Zika Trials as 12 Groups Seek Vaccine

text: IT services provider Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp forecast its slowest quarterly revenue growth in 14 years, adding to mounting worries about clients keeping a tight lid on technology spending.
headline: Cognizant Forecasts Slowest Revenue Growth in 14 Years

text: A leopard wandered into a school in southern India and injured three people as it tried to escape, officials said.
headline: Leopard Wanders South Indian School, Injures 3 Before Caught

text: One of the women who has accused former U.S. President Bill Clinton of sexual assault says she has agreed to work for an anti-Clinton political group being formed by a former advisor to Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump.
headline: Woman Who Accused Bill Clinton of Assault to Campaign Against Hillary Presidential Run

text: After the attacks in Paris and New Year's security scares, Germans have been snapping up self-defense equipment like stun guns — to the delight of a Czech manufacturer who corners the market.
headline: Stun Guns in Demand in Germany Amid Security Concerns

text: Madrid city hall apologized Monday to parents for exposing their children to a violent puppet show, but says jailing the puppeteers for allegedly praising terrorism was disproportionate.
headline: Spain: Madrid City Calls for Release of Puppeteers

text: The worst health scare in recent history is not keeping Brazilians from their annual Carnival revelry, with millions of partiers swarming streets and some making fun of the mosquito that spreads Zika and other viruses.
headline: Carnival Roars Ahead in Brazil Despite Zika Health Scare

text: Experts on microcephaly, the birth defect that has sparked alarm in the current Zika virus outbreak, say they are struck by the severity of a small number of cases they have reviewed from Brazil.
headline: Doctors Puzzle Over Severity of Defects in Some Brazilian Babies

text: The rapidly spreading Zika virus is discouraging many Americans from traveling to Latin America and the Caribbean, with 41 percent of those aware of the disease saying they are less likely to take such a trip, a Reuters/Ipsos poll shows.
headline: Exclusive: Zika Virus Discourages Many Americans From Latin America Travel

text: When an earthquake struck southern Taiwan in the early hours of Saturday, Chang Chun-jung thought it was all over.
headline: Mother, Sons Freed From Debris, Dark and Confusion in Quake-Toppled Taiwan Home

text: The new CEO of Credit Suisse has proposed that its board make a "significant" cut in his bonus after the Swiss bank posted disappointing earnings last week and announced 4,000 job cuts.
headline: After Big Loss, Credit Suisse CEO Asks Board: Cut My Bonus

text: U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump came to the small town of Plymouth in the New Hampshire mountains on Sunday and promised to lower prescription drug prices, improve education and help heroin addicts get treatment.
headline: Before New Hampshire Primary, Trump Campaign Shows Mellower Side

text: A man has died after starting a Raleigh race in which contestants are supposed to also eat a dozen Krispy Kreme doughnuts midway through the competition.
headline: Man Dies After Starting Krispy Kreme Challenge in Raleigh

text: The Philippines' top diplomat, who was behind a bold government move to challenge the validity of China's vast territorial claims in the South China Sea at an international tribunal, has resigned due to health reasons, officials said Monday.
headline: Top Philippine Diplomat and China Critic Resigns Over Health

text: Hundreds of Czech taxi drivers are blocking a major road in downtown Prague to demand higher pay and protest alternative services such as Uber.
headline: Taxi in Prague Block Traffic, Demand Higher Pay, Ban on Uber

text: Stoke City players should start taking more risks to end their four-game winless streak in the Premier League, manager Mark Hughes said after Saturday's 3-0 drubbing at the hands of Everton.
headline: Stoke Must Take More Risks, Says Manager Hughes

text: U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump came to the small town of Plymouth in the New Hampshire mountains on Sunday and promised to lower prescription drug prices, improve education and help heroin addicts get treatment.
headline: Before New Hampshire Primary, Trump Campaign Shows Mellower Side

text: Ramzan Kadyrov, hardline leader of Russia's Chechen region and close ally of President Vladimir Putin, said Chechen spies loyal to Moscow had infiltrated Islamic State in Syria and were   gathering intelligence for Russian air force bombing strikes.
headline: Putin Ally Says Chechen Spies Infiltrate Islamic State in Syria

text: West Ham United will be without defender James Tomkins for Tuesday's FA Cup fourth-round replay against Liverpool and the next few games, manager Slaven Bilic said on Monday.
headline: West Ham's Tomkins Ruled Out With Calf Injury

text: Rescuers in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan pulled another person out alive from the wreckage of a collapsed building on Monday, Taiwan television stations said, more than 60 hours after an earthquake hit the island.
headline: One More Person Pulled Alive From Rubble After Taiwan Quake-TV

text: Britain's top share index fell on Monday to its lowest level in more than two weeks, weighed down by falls in banking stocks to multi-year lows and weakness in the tech sector.
headline: FTSE Falls to Two-And-a-Half Week Low, Hit by Banks and Tech

text: Rescuers in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan pulled another person out alive from the wreckage of a collapsed building on Monday, Taiwan television stations said, more than 60 hours after an earthquake hit the island.
headline: One More Person Pulled Alive From Rubble After Taiwan Quake: TV

text: The Syrian army advanced towards the Turkish border on Monday in a major offensive backed by Russia and Iran that rebels say now threatens the future of their nearly five-year-old insurrection against President Bashar al-Assad.
headline: Russian Firepower Helps Syrian Forces Edge Towards Turkey Border

text: The Syrian army advanced toward the Turkish border on Monday in a major offensive backed by Russia and Iran that rebels say now threatens the future of their nearly five-year-old insurrection against President Bashar al-Assad.
headline: Russian Firepower Helps Syrian Forces Edge Toward Turkey Border

text: Russia's state security service says it has detained seven people in the country's Ural mountain region on suspicion of terrorist activities.
headline: Russian Authorities Detain 7 on Suspicion of Terrorist Plot

text: Jerome Cahuzac was the face of France's fight against tax evaders — until he was forced to acknowledge that he himself was dodging taxes, hiding money in tax havens around the world.
headline: French Ex-Minister in Court Over Tax Fraud, Money Laundering

text: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about today:
headline: 10 Things to Know for Today

text: Syrian army troops recaptured a new village north of Aleppo Monday, bringing troops and allied militiamen to within a few kilometers of the Turkish border as part of a major Russian-backed offensive in the area, the Syrian government and opposition activists said.
headline: Syria Troops Make More Gains in Aleppo, Near Turkish Border

text: Global mining firm Rio Tinto is looking for opportunities to expand in Africa as it bets on long term demand growth for minerals, a senior executive said on Monday.
headline: Rio Tinto Says Seeking Growth Opportunities in Africa

text: Southampton's five-game unbeaten run in the Premier League, which has lifted them to seventh in the table, has halted a worrying mid-season slump, according to defender Virgil van Dijk.
headline: Unbeaten Run Has Saints Back on Track, Says Van Dijk

text: A 90-year-old Spanish woman wrapped in a fur coat and woollen scarf stood over a deep open grave and murmured "my father" to the unearthed skeleton lying at the bottom.
headline: Spanish Grave Opened on Order of Argentine Judge Unearths Painful Past

text: Orange Polska, Poland's largest telecoms operator, is seen shifting to a net loss of 141 million zlotys ($36 million) in the fourth quarter, hit by high seasonal costs and one-off restructuring provisions, a Reuters poll showed on Monday.
headline: Polish Orange Unit Seen Shifting to Fourth-Quarter Loss on One-Off Hit-Reuters Poll

text: The Kremlin strongly condemned on Monday North Korea's latest rocket launch, calling it a violation of the international law.
headline: Kremlin Strongly Condemns North Korea's Rocket Launch

text: A suspected suicide bomber who blew a hole in the fuselage of a  Daallo Airlines plane last week and forced it to make an emergency landing in Mogadishu was meant to be on a Turkish Airlines flight, Daallo's chief executive said on Monday.
headline: Somalia Plane Bomber Was Meant to Board Turkish Flight: Airline Executive

text: Chancellor George Osborne's ambition to run a budget surplus by the end of the decade could easily be frustrated by disappointing tax revenues, the Institute for Fiscal Studies said on Monday.
headline: Weak UK Tax Revenue Could Thwart Osborne's Surplus Aim, Thinktank Says

text: Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe is looking to Leicester City for inspiration as his relegation-threatened club bid to stay in the Premier League.
headline: Leicester Story Can Inspire Sunderland Escape, Says Defoe

text: In a country that pays as much attention to England's football Premier League as it does to local politics, one film director  is seeking to rekindle lost pride in a national game that has languished in the doldrums for four decades.
headline: Malaysian Filmmaker Seeks to Rekindle Lost Pride in National Football

text: U.S. President Barack Obama and other world leaders called on governments to be responsive to and inclusive of their citizens at a conference in Dubai on Monday, as the unrest of the Arab Spring reverberates across the Middle East.
headline: Call for Responsive Governments at Dubai Summit Amid Turmoil

text: Russia's FSB security service said on Monday it had arrested seven Islamic State militants in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg who it said had been planning bomb attacks in Moscow, St Petersburg and the Sverdlovsk region.
headline: Russia Says Arrests Seven Islamic State Militants Over Attack Plot

text: Retired archbishop Desmond Tutu has defended the reconciliation policy that ended white minority rule in South Africa, saying the country has social and economic problems largely because of later mismanagement.
